description: This course will cover everything you need to create a presentation in PowerPoint.  These episodes start at the very beginning by exploring the PowerPoint environment, how to add slides to a presentation, insert text and images into slides, create tables and charts, apply design themes, enhance with animation, and prepare to deliver final presentation.
descriptionMD: This course will cover everything you need to create a presentation in PowerPoint.  These episodes start at the very beginning by exploring the PowerPoint environment, how to add slides to a presentation, insert text and images into slides, create tables and charts, apply design themes, enhance with animation, and prepare to deliver final presentation.
name: PowerPoint 2016
subtitle: Presentation application to create slide shows

episodes.description: This course will cover everything you need to create a presentation in PowerPoint. These episodes start at the very beginning by exploring the PowerPoint environment, how to add slides to a presentation, insert text and images into slides, create tables and charts, apply design themes, enhance with animation, and prepare to deliver final presentation.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.300
>> [SOUND]
>> Hello.

2
00:00:04.300 --> 00:00:08.020
>> We've got an exiting new show
coming your way, at ItProTV.

3
00:00:08.020 --> 00:00:08.910
PowerPoint 2016.

4
00:00:08.910 --> 00:00:12.350
Here to tell us all about it,
is Ms Vonne Smith.

5
00:00:12.350 --> 00:00:13.020
>> Thanks, Mike.

6
00:00:13.020 --> 00:00:16.150
Yes, we're going to be starting in
PowerPoint from the very beginning.

7
00:00:16.150 --> 00:00:19.900
We're go through our environment and be
able to identify things like the ribbon,

8
00:00:19.900 --> 00:00:24.620
and the status bar, and the title bar to
get us familiar with our environment to be

9
00:00:24.620 --> 00:00:29.330
comfortable adding in those informations
that we want in our slides.

10
00:00:29.330 --> 00:00:32.660
We will be adding slides, and
we'll be changing our layouts for

11
00:00:32.660 --> 00:00:36.690
our slides to be able to have a layout
of what we want to be able to do,

12
00:00:36.690 --> 00:00:42.750
whether it's adding text, or do we want to
compare different items and add headings?

13
00:00:42.750 --> 00:00:46.060
Maybe we wanted to add some images in
there and just have a blank slide layout.

14
00:00:46.060 --> 00:00:48.770
So we'll be going over all
of those different options.

15
00:00:48.770 --> 00:00:54.200
We will be adding text, images,
charts, tables, smart art.

16
00:00:54.200 --> 00:00:57.270
And then, we're going to be
formatting all of those elements

17
00:00:57.270 --> 00:01:01.030
with nice design themes to make
everything look pleasing to the eye.

18
00:01:02.060 --> 00:01:03.570
We will be adding animations,

19
00:01:03.570 --> 00:01:06.130
we'll also be adding some slide
transitions to be able to give us

20
00:01:06.130 --> 00:01:10.290
a little extra pizzazz when we're going
to be delivering our presentation.

21
00:01:10.290 --> 00:01:13.510
This series expects that you do not
really know anything about PowerPoint to

22
00:01:13.510 --> 00:01:14.320
begin with.

23
00:01:14.320 --> 00:01:17.680
So if that's where you're starting at,
then this is the series to watch.

24
00:01:17.680 --> 00:01:18.402
I hope you enjoy.

25
00:01:18.402 --> 00:01:20.358
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne, introduce us to PowerPoint 2016.  They discuss what it is and why we would choose to use it.  They take the time to also show some of the different powerpoint plans users are likely to work with in the workplace.  Vonne and Ronnie also show how to get started working in PowerPoint from scratch!
episodes.title: Introduction to PowerPoint
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.573
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.573 --> 00:00:04.946
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.946 --> 00:00:08.264
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.264 --> 00:00:12.006
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.006 --> 00:00:15.440
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.440 --> 00:00:16.820
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:16.820 --> 00:00:21.310
And today we're gonna be inside
of Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

8
00:00:21.310 --> 00:00:24.260
We're learning all about it, and
we just need to get started.

9
00:00:24.260 --> 00:00:27.585
And we have our subject matter expert
here to help us, Miss Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:27.585 --> 00:00:30.620
Vonne, welcome to our show,
and how are you doing today?

11
00:00:30.620 --> 00:00:32.540
>> I'm doing great, thank you so
much for having me.

12
00:00:32.540 --> 00:00:35.150
>> Well,
we are glad that you're here as we start

13
00:00:35.150 --> 00:00:38.460
to take a look at getting started
into Microsoft PowerPoint.

14
00:00:38.460 --> 00:00:39.840
Vonne, where's a good place for

15
00:00:39.840 --> 00:00:43.220
us to begin when we really
need to learn about this?

16
00:00:43.220 --> 00:00:46.060
>> Well, in this episode what we're gonna
do is we're gonna start from the very

17
00:00:46.060 --> 00:00:48.930
beginning, the really beginning,
beginning.

18
00:00:48.930 --> 00:00:51.880
Of where we're just gonna start
talking about PowerPoint.

19
00:00:51.880 --> 00:00:54.420
What is it, what does it do?

20
00:00:54.420 --> 00:00:57.280
And just kind of,
how do we even get it started?

21
00:00:57.280 --> 00:00:58.620
How do we even launch the program?

22
00:00:58.620 --> 00:01:02.246
So I made a PowerPoint to
talk about PowerPoint.

23
00:01:02.246 --> 00:01:03.082
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

24
00:01:03.082 --> 00:01:06.415
I'm gonna just jump right in and
get going.

25
00:01:06.415 --> 00:01:07.375
What is PowerPoint?

26
00:01:07.375 --> 00:01:08.575
So here is the introduction.

27
00:01:08.575 --> 00:01:13.685
So PowerPoint is
a presentation application.

28
00:01:13.685 --> 00:01:17.895
It is the product that you
use to create slides, and

29
00:01:17.895 --> 00:01:22.675
when you run your slides,
it becomes a slideshow.

30
00:01:22.675 --> 00:01:26.210
And you can see that I put up in
that first bullet point there that

31
00:01:26.210 --> 00:01:28.180
I said it's a presentation application.

32
00:01:28.180 --> 00:01:30.290
But you could also use the word software,

33
00:01:30.290 --> 00:01:32.540
you could use the word program,
application.

34
00:01:32.540 --> 00:01:37.134
Those words are really interchangeable,
and a lot of people use them when they're

35
00:01:37.134 --> 00:01:43.300
describing any type of product,
software application, program.

36
00:01:43.300 --> 00:01:45.570
PowerPoint, Word, Excel,
anything within Office,

37
00:01:45.570 --> 00:01:47.300
you can kinda use those
words interchangeably.

38
00:01:47.300 --> 00:01:49.893
So I wanted to go ahead and
just throw that in there right there.

39
00:01:49.893 --> 00:01:53.791
>> All right, Vonne, when in the world
would I normally need PowerPoint?

40
00:01:53.791 --> 00:01:57.540
I know, let's say for example,
that my daughter when she was in school,

41
00:01:57.540 --> 00:01:59.850
she used PowerPoint to
make a presentation.

42
00:01:59.850 --> 00:02:01.230
But I'm an adult,

43
00:02:01.230 --> 00:02:05.130
I'm working at an office, when in
the world would I ever use PowerPoint?

44
00:02:05.130 --> 00:02:05.906
>> All the time.
[LAUGH]

45
00:02:05.906 --> 00:02:06.840
>> Okay.

46
00:02:06.840 --> 00:02:11.930
>> I mean if you work in an office,
like right now I'm giving a presentation

47
00:02:11.930 --> 00:02:16.346
on PowerPoint, on a subject that I would
like to give you some information about.

48
00:02:16.346 --> 00:02:19.960
And I'm going to be standing up and
talking to people, PowerPoint is a great

49
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:25.645
tool to help you convey that information
with graphics and some words.

50
00:02:25.645 --> 00:02:27.800
Then of course one of the biggest things,

51
00:02:27.800 --> 00:02:29.837
you don't wanna just read
directly from your slides.

52
00:02:29.837 --> 00:02:35.270
We will have a whole episode on going
over what makes a PowerPoint presentation

53
00:02:35.270 --> 00:02:39.710
effective, and making sure you're
creating a good PowerPoint presentation.

54
00:02:39.710 --> 00:02:41.210
But It could be used for anything.

55
00:02:41.210 --> 00:02:43.880
You think about teachers
using it in a classroom.

56
00:02:43.880 --> 00:02:50.340
A church, a lot of churches use
PowerPoints to convey or bring a message.

57
00:02:50.340 --> 00:02:53.750
Anything really,
students use it to do presentations.

58
00:02:53.750 --> 00:02:55.240
It's all over the place.

59
00:02:55.240 --> 00:02:57.260
>> Yeah, Vonne,
I see the advantage of that.

60
00:02:57.260 --> 00:02:59.580
Because a lot of times
when I went to school,

61
00:02:59.580 --> 00:03:02.910
PowerPoint really wasn't
a big product at that point.

62
00:03:02.910 --> 00:03:06.190
It was all about handing in papers and
just turning in papers.

63
00:03:06.190 --> 00:03:09.730
Or being able to do a little bit of
a public speech in front of people.

64
00:03:09.730 --> 00:03:12.940
But the idea of PowerPoint,
I think, what makes it nice and

65
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:14.160
powerful is what you talked about.

66
00:03:14.160 --> 00:03:18.050
It allows us to draw together media
as well as the words that we want

67
00:03:18.050 --> 00:03:20.060
to really help make the point
that we want to as well.

68
00:03:20.060 --> 00:03:22.800
All right, so Vonne,
where can we get started?

69
00:03:22.800 --> 00:03:24.950
How can I get PowerPoint on my computer?

70
00:03:24.950 --> 00:03:26.892
>> Exactly, so next slide.

71
00:03:26.892 --> 00:03:28.401
[LAUGH] Let me jump down into here.

72
00:03:28.401 --> 00:03:36.930
So PowerPoint is a product within
the Office 365 suite of applications.

73
00:03:36.930 --> 00:03:37.560
And you can see,

74
00:03:37.560 --> 00:03:41.020
I have this slide here where I just
kind of threw all of the different

75
00:03:41.020 --> 00:03:45.860
Office products that you will be able to
see if you go to the Microsoft website.

76
00:03:45.860 --> 00:03:48.500
So I put the ones on
the left that we have Word,

77
00:03:48.500 --> 00:03:50.840
Excel, Outlook, PowerPoint, and Access.

78
00:03:50.840 --> 00:03:55.505
Cuz these are the ones that a lot of
people kinda typically find within

79
00:03:55.505 --> 00:03:57.765
an Office product.

80
00:03:57.765 --> 00:04:00.715
And there's another side in just a second
that talks about all the different

81
00:04:00.715 --> 00:04:01.935
versions that you can get.

82
00:04:01.935 --> 00:04:04.506
But I went ahead and
put some other ones on there,

83
00:04:04.506 --> 00:04:08.281
because OneNote is a product that you
actually will see a lot nowadays.

84
00:04:08.281 --> 00:04:11.731
You'll probably actually see that more
than Access sometimes when you're buying

85
00:04:11.731 --> 00:04:15.360
these bundles or these different suites
of application that you wanna get.

86
00:04:15.360 --> 00:04:19.392
And some other kinda outliers, if you
wanna see, Project, Visio, Publisher, and

87
00:04:19.392 --> 00:04:22.370
InfoPath those are once that
you'll be seeing here and there.

88
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:26.911
And I put off to the very,
very right Sway, Teams, SharePoint, Lync,

89
00:04:26.911 --> 00:04:30.050
which is really Skype for
Business and OneDrive.

90
00:04:30.050 --> 00:04:32.034
I'm just throwing it on this slide so

91
00:04:32.034 --> 00:04:36.386
you will be able to recognize these things
when you go to the Microsoft website and

92
00:04:36.386 --> 00:04:38.826
be able to see all of
these different things.

93
00:04:38.826 --> 00:04:43.897
So you're going to have to determine
what product is best for you.

94
00:04:43.897 --> 00:04:45.385
And so you can see that they,

95
00:04:45.385 --> 00:04:49.160
on this I actually just took
a screenshot of the Microsoft website.

96
00:04:49.160 --> 00:04:51.070
There are a bunch of different pans.

97
00:04:51.070 --> 00:04:54.440
You have like, your personal use,
you have office use, for business,

98
00:04:54.440 --> 00:04:58.646
you have for it education, so you get
the student pricing a lot of times.

99
00:04:58.646 --> 00:05:02.820
And that's just for,
if you are purchasing it yourself.

100
00:05:02.820 --> 00:05:05.070
Because if you have a large organization,

101
00:05:05.070 --> 00:05:10.300
then you have IT people that are going
to be purchasing these products for you.

102
00:05:10.300 --> 00:05:13.190
And so that's something that
you'll just have to talk to

103
00:05:13.190 --> 00:05:18.230
whoever is in charge of your IT, no matter
how large or small your organization is.

104
00:05:18.230 --> 00:05:21.300
And how they're going to be Installing or

105
00:05:21.300 --> 00:05:25.010
having the products on whatever
computer that you're using.

106
00:05:25.010 --> 00:05:28.720
>> Now Vonne,
you made a key word point for

107
00:05:28.720 --> 00:05:31.830
me, which is the idea that
I can get this for free.

108
00:05:31.830 --> 00:05:32.750
How is that possible?

109
00:05:32.750 --> 00:05:33.830
>> That's a great point, Ronnie.

110
00:05:33.830 --> 00:05:39.000
Because yes, you can actually
get these products for free.

111
00:05:39.000 --> 00:05:41.820
So actually I have another slide
that's supposed to get into that.

112
00:05:41.820 --> 00:05:47.640
So you have PowerPoint, and you can have
it locally installed on your computer.

113
00:05:47.640 --> 00:05:50.840
So you bought one of those plans, and
you've actually purchased this product.

114
00:05:50.840 --> 00:05:55.150
You can install it on the machine and
have it just like you'd have

115
00:05:55.150 --> 00:05:57.890
any other product on your machine,
so that was a local install.

116
00:05:57.890 --> 00:06:02.284
When you actually do that, you’re actually
bringing that up to, it's PowerPoint 2016.

117
00:06:02.284 --> 00:06:06.737
So yeah, we have PowerPoint 365, or
Office 365, but then when it’s your

118
00:06:06.737 --> 00:06:11.192
machine its PowerPoint 2016, yes that’s
exactly what its supposed to be.

119
00:06:11.192 --> 00:06:15.510
But on the other side, one of
the kinda nice features about Office

120
00:06:15.510 --> 00:06:19.199
365 is that you can use all
of these same products, or

121
00:06:19.199 --> 00:06:23.460
software, or programs or
whatever you wanna call it, online.

122
00:06:23.460 --> 00:06:25.420
So you can use it through
your web browser, and

123
00:06:25.420 --> 00:06:29.990
that's the part where you can
access these products or free.

124
00:06:29.990 --> 00:06:33.750
All you have to do is sign up for
a Microsoft account, and

125
00:06:33.750 --> 00:06:35.880
you create a online account.

126
00:06:35.880 --> 00:06:40.473
And then you can use the free versions
of PowerPoint, Word, Excel, and

127
00:06:40.473 --> 00:06:43.579
I believe your mail comes
through there as well.

128
00:06:43.579 --> 00:06:47.805
So you can use all of those kind of like
the big products we'll call them, for

129
00:06:47.805 --> 00:06:50.924
free by just signing up for
the Microsoft application.

130
00:06:50.924 --> 00:06:54.485
So whether you're using a free version,
a paid version,

131
00:06:54.485 --> 00:06:57.248
whether you're doing it locally or online,

132
00:06:57.248 --> 00:07:02.070
that does make a difference, because
there will be some slight differences.

133
00:07:02.070 --> 00:07:06.312
Well, a lot of the, adding a slide,
and running a show, that's going to

134
00:07:06.312 --> 00:07:11.090
be the same across all of your products,
whether you're on a PC or on a Mac.

135
00:07:11.090 --> 00:07:16.080
But it is something that you definitely
should take note of when you're

136
00:07:16.080 --> 00:07:19.570
using your PowerPoint and
watching these episodes, so.

137
00:07:19.570 --> 00:07:22.730
>> Yeah, Vonne, that makes a very good
point here that the very fact that,

138
00:07:22.730 --> 00:07:23.690
if we do get it for free,

139
00:07:23.690 --> 00:07:28.760
we might find some limitations of
what we might show here on the show.

140
00:07:28.760 --> 00:07:31.290
But at the same time,
it's enough to get somebody started,

141
00:07:31.290 --> 00:07:33.700
to be able to work with
PowerPoint right away.

142
00:07:33.700 --> 00:07:35.780
And Vonne mentioned those
different plans and

143
00:07:35.780 --> 00:07:39.050
it really does boil down to whether
your company is purchasing it,

144
00:07:39.050 --> 00:07:42.430
whether you're purchasing it, or whether
you're just trying to use it at all.

145
00:07:42.430 --> 00:07:43.760
Which ones you'll actually end up with.

146
00:07:43.760 --> 00:07:45.910
Most companies will of
course end up paying for it.

147
00:07:45.910 --> 00:07:49.750
But if you're on your own and you're
going man, I really can't afford it,

148
00:07:49.750 --> 00:07:51.310
you can just connect online and

149
00:07:51.310 --> 00:07:54.748
be able to use it without having to
really pay that much for it at all.

150
00:07:54.748 --> 00:07:58.292
Free is kind of the key and
operative word which is also nice too.

151
00:07:58.292 --> 00:08:02.967
Now, Vonne, as we started using these
we're gonna end up creating PowerPoint

152
00:08:02.967 --> 00:08:06.121
files, I'm assuming is
what we're gonna created.

153
00:08:06.121 --> 00:08:09.991
And I've noticed something over time
is that these files have changed.

154
00:08:09.991 --> 00:08:12.660
What are we talking about when we take
a look at this idea of the change?

155
00:08:12.660 --> 00:08:14.460
>> You have a great transition for
me there, Ronnie.

156
00:08:14.460 --> 00:08:18.803
So onto the next slide, you can see
that we have version and file types.

157
00:08:18.803 --> 00:08:23.238
Because just like Ronnie was saying,
when we're creating

158
00:08:23.238 --> 00:08:28.124
a PowerPoint presentation,
we are creating a PPTX file format.

159
00:08:28.124 --> 00:08:30.980
So that's just PowerPoint, that ppt.

160
00:08:30.980 --> 00:08:34.301
So you can actually see it
referred a lot to as ppt.

161
00:08:34.301 --> 00:08:37.663
But it has that x, because there's been
many different versions of PowerPoint

162
00:08:37.663 --> 00:08:38.673
throughout the years.

163
00:08:38.673 --> 00:08:43.932
I actually found a note that it was
originally created for Mac in 1987.

164
00:08:43.932 --> 00:08:47.360
So that was actually conceptualized, and

165
00:08:47.360 --> 00:08:51.510
its gone through the different versions,
both in the PC versions and

166
00:08:51.510 --> 00:08:55.460
the Mac versions, and they have
the years of which they came out.

167
00:08:55.460 --> 00:09:00.086
So you could see that the .pptx
file format has been around ever

168
00:09:00.086 --> 00:09:01.927
since Office 2007.

169
00:09:01.927 --> 00:09:05.772
There was a huge jump from, and
actually, it's right behind my head, but

170
00:09:05.772 --> 00:09:09.206
there was 2003 to 2007 there
was a pretty big split there.

171
00:09:09.206 --> 00:09:12.496
Because I think before that,
they were doing 2000, 2002, 2003.

172
00:09:12.496 --> 00:09:16.158
So there was quite a few versions but
big gap, and

173
00:09:16.158 --> 00:09:21.710
they jumped right into an extended
version of all of the Office products.

174
00:09:21.710 --> 00:09:25.230
And that's why if you think extended,
you got an x at the end.

175
00:09:25.230 --> 00:09:26.670
I mean, that's how I always thought of it.

176
00:09:26.670 --> 00:09:29.290
I don't really know if that's
their logic behind it, but

177
00:09:29.290 --> 00:09:33.830
it did extend all of the file formats and
all of the Office products.

178
00:09:33.830 --> 00:09:39.276
So doc was for Word and
became docx, ppt became pptx.

179
00:09:39.276 --> 00:09:43.701
And it's just a good thing to point out,
because while we're in,

180
00:09:43.701 --> 00:09:45.608
this is 2017 right now.

181
00:09:45.608 --> 00:09:51.179
You could have files that are in
an older version from those 2003 days

182
00:09:51.179 --> 00:09:57.130
that is in a ppt extension, and that's
just at least something to point out.

183
00:09:57.130 --> 00:10:00.400
And I put all the icons on there, so
you can get a little idea about it.

184
00:10:00.400 --> 00:10:03.682
And a big thing down below there,
you can see compatibility mode.

185
00:10:03.682 --> 00:10:07.380
I put that in there,
because that's where in the title bar,

186
00:10:07.380 --> 00:10:10.063
when we get into actually the environment,

187
00:10:10.063 --> 00:10:14.721
the title bar will actually have
compatibility mode right there at the top.

188
00:10:14.721 --> 00:10:16.788
And that's a big indication to you that,

189
00:10:16.788 --> 00:10:20.570
that is the file format that

00:33:53.410 --> 00:33:58.350
And that's a big thing between
your Office applications as how

637
00:33:58.350 --> 00:34:01.390
you want things to be pasted
to wherever you're going.

638
00:34:01.390 --> 00:34:05.400
And we'll be demonstrating that
as we go through these lessons.

639
00:34:05.400 --> 00:34:08.480
But cut, copy and paste, big, big thing.

640
00:34:08.480 --> 00:34:12.100
Can save you lots and lots of time and
I just wanted to go ahead and

641
00:34:12.100 --> 00:34:13.050
point that out.

642
00:34:13.050 --> 00:34:13.750
>> All right, Vonne.

643
00:34:13.750 --> 00:34:19.260
Well like I said, you've shown us a very
tremendous amount of information for

644
00:34:19.260 --> 00:34:22.100
our very first session in
taking a look at PowerPoint.

645
00:34:22.100 --> 00:34:23.330
Learn that what you saw here, right?

646
00:34:23.330 --> 00:34:26.460
Is Vonne telling us how to really
get started with PowerPoint?

647
00:34:26.460 --> 00:34:29.620
She talked about the basic product
itself and what the point is,

648
00:34:29.620 --> 00:34:31.290
of course, behind using it.

649
00:34:31.290 --> 00:34:35.300
And we also saw some of the basic
mechanics of how we get to open a file,

650
00:34:35.300 --> 00:34:38.660
as well as save a file and
understand the differences there, too.

651
00:34:38.660 --> 00:34:41.860
And understand a little bit about the
navigation of these files as well which

652
00:34:41.860 --> 00:34:45.973
is very important as we get started to
learn a little bit more about PowerPoint

653
00:34:45.973 --> 00:34:46.672
as well.

654
00:34:46.672 --> 00:34:50.538
All right well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode.

655
00:34:50.538 --> 00:34:54.780
Thank you Vonne for
showing us these neat starts and

656
00:34:54.780 --> 00:34:58.130
beginnings and also thank you for
watching today.

657
00:34:58.130 --> 00:35:01.520
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

658
00:35:01.520 --> 00:35:02.470
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

659
00:35:02.470 --> 00:35:07.337
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft PowerPoint 2016 shows.

660
00:35:07.337 --> 00:35:13.286
[MUSIC]

661
00:35:13.286 --> 00:35:16.596
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: in this episode, Ronnie and Vonne take a look at the powerpoint environment.  They show how to navigate in the PowerPoint environment and many of the different tools users will access.  Vonne demonstrates how the environment changes and the different ways to customize and use powerpoint tools.  She also demonstrates some of the different elements that show up when looking at the slides pane.  Lastly, she shows how to run the PowerPoint itself.
episodes.title: The PowerPoint Environment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.580 --> 00:00:02.072
Welcome to ITProTV.
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.072 --> 00:00:04.130
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.130 --> 00:00:08.375
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.375 --> 00:00:11.049
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.049 --> 00:00:15.680
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.680 --> 00:00:21.040
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and today
you're watching Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

7
00:00:21.040 --> 00:00:24.960

And we're gonna actually

11
00:00:30.850 --> 00:00:34.280
>> I'm good, glad to be here
>> Well, Vonne, as we get started and

12

this as the PowerPoint environment.

13
00:00:38.570 --> 00:00:42.410
Why is it so important that we understand
the environment that we're working in?

14
00:00:42.410 --> 00:00:47.000
>> Well, it's kind of like walking
into a kitchen or into a house.

15
00:00:47.000 --> 00:00:52.294
You wanna know where the drawer is for
the spoons, and where do we find the cups.

16
00:00:52.294 --> 00:00:54.220
And where's the bedrooms,
where's the bathrooms?

17
00:00:54.220 --> 00:00:58.140
All those kinds of things of just getting
familiarized with your environment.

18
00:00:58.140 --> 00:01:01.950
Because it is important, because knowing
where to go will make it easier for

19
00:01:01.950 --> 00:01:03.400
you to use the product.

20
00:01:03.400 --> 00:01:04.270
>> There's no doubt, Vonne.

21
00:01:04.270 --> 00:01:08.490
I've found myself many times in different
types of applications out there,

22
00:01:08.490 --> 00:01:11.490

23
00:01:11.490 --> 00:01:15.648
So what you're gonna do today is to help
us to get started with PowerPoint to learn

24
00:01:15.648 --> 00:01:18.070
really the entire Office environment.

25
00:01:18.070 --> 00:01:21.058
But we'll end up finding out something
that once we learned it in PowerPoint,

26
00:01:21.058 --> 00:01:26.650
don't the actual skills tend to transfer
over into other types of products, too?

27
00:01:26.650 --> 00:01:29.964
>> Exactly, yes, we're going to go
over really not just the PowerPoint

28
00:01:29.964 --> 00:01:32.620

the Office environment in general.

29
00:01:32.620 --> 00:01:34.412
And I'm going to use
their technical names,

30
00:01:34.412 --> 00:01:37.920
their real names of what they're referred
to, because it's always good to know that.

31
00:01:37.920 --> 00:01:42.438
Because I do tend to say that thing over
there, or that line with an X through it.

32
00:01:42.438 --> 00:01:43.940
It's like, well, what exactly is that?

33
00:01:43.940 --> 00:01:48.060
So I will use our technical words and
get you familiarized with the quick

34
00:01:48.060 --> 00:01:51.916
access toolbar and the ribbon, and
what is that, and where is it?

35
00:01:51.916 --> 00:01:54.640
And so we're just gonna go ahead and
jump right in.

36
00:01:54.640 --> 00:01:58.100
>> All right, so Vonne,
where do we best get started if we're

00:01:58.100 --> 00:02:00.410

We know that in a previous episode,

00:02:02.619 --> 00:02:04.530
you kind of walked us

But now, we're really starting
to get interested in it.

00:02:06.800 --> 00:02:08.000
Where should I begin?

00:02:08.000 --> 00:02:11.170
>> Yes, well, for us, for me,
since I haven't even opened up PowerPoint,

00:02:11.170 --> 00:02:12.080

00:02:12.080 --> 00:02:14.160
So I'm just gonna go ahead and

45
00:02:14.160 --> 00:02:17.640
type in my little search guy
that I'm typing in PowerPoint.

46
00:02:17.640 --> 00:02:21.550
So you go ahead load, or
start the program, for the most part.

47
00:02:21.550 --> 00:02:25.530
And we went over our start screen
in some of our previous episodes.

48
00:02:25.530 --> 00:02:28.000
And what we're going to do is we're
going to actually open up a file

49
00:02:28.000 --> 00:02:29.610

50
00:02:29.610 --> 00:02:33.920
Because when I try to teach things,
I almost like to teach it backwards.

51
00:02:33.920 --> 00:02:36.060
I wanna show you where you can go,

00:02:36.060 --> 00:02:38.890
what's the finished product,
before you even start.

53
00:02:38.890 --> 00:02:40.190
It's always like designing backwards.

54
00:02:40.190 --> 00:02:43.342
That's how I always approach a lot of

55
00:02:43.342 --> 00:02:45.300

56
00:02:45.300 --> 00:02:47.820
So I'm going to go ahead and

00:02:47.820 --> 00:02:52.230
And I have a file called

But we know that we could go and

But these things that you have,

00:04:46.390 --> 00:04:49.000

And then we have some of our
Share options over here,

As we said, that these are the tabs.

>> Yes, exactly.

Well, that's a good observation.

The reason why they're grayed out is

00:07:51.742 --> 00:07:53.968
I'm sure you all are just

All right, well, If you double click any

It is personal preference really.

Some people might wanna design this way or

00:08:36.330 --> 00:08:39.110
I tend to like to see all

00:08:39.110 --> 00:08:43.454
So I can double click it again and

And something newer, or at least in some

00:08:50.361 --> 00:08:53.650
they have this little button

167
00:08:53.650 --> 00:08:56.429
It's like this little right there.

That little guy that is

So, if I click it you can see that it

170
00:09:04.380 --> 00:09:05.740

171
00:09:05.740 --> 00:09:08.205
And that's the one that we're on,

00:09:18.820 --> 00:09:23.502

176
00:09:23.502 --> 00:09:26.892

where they've got PowerPoint open.

178
00:09:30.680 --> 00:09:34.880
They might be looking at your particular

00:09:34.880 --> 00:09:38.700
And they say hay, that doesn't look

180
00:09:38.700 --> 00:09:41.273
So, Yvonne, what's going on there if
you actually see some things that look

00:09:41.273 --> 00:09:43.302

what you're actually showing.

182
00:09:43.302 --> 00:09:48.099
>> Yes, you're highlighting
the autosizing of the Office environment

183
00:09:48.099 --> 00:09:50.300
depending on your resolution.

184
00:09:50.300 --> 00:09:54.498
So, I have a specific screen

185
00:09:54.498 --> 00:09:57.840
And so, specifically,
if I go to the home tab right now,

00:09:57.840 --> 00:10:01.060

00:10:01.060 --> 00:10:05.400
Well if I had a higher resolution monitor,

00:10:05.400 --> 00:10:08.180
you can actually see names

189
00:10:08.180 --> 00:10:10.940
I think this is a slide layout,

190
00:10:10.940 --> 00:10:12.402
I think those are the names next to it.

191
00:10:12.402 --> 00:10:15.466
If you see names that's just

192
00:10:15.466 --> 00:10:19.076
it's like more real estate basically for

193
00:10:19.076 --> 00:10:20.800
And you probably see shapes and arrange.

194
00:10:20.800 --> 00:10:24.564
So I'm gonna actually show you the resort

So I'm going to show you
everything in this presentation.

423
00:22:03.510 --> 00:22:06.220
And everything that we have on these
slides with the layouts and the pictures,

424
00:22:06.220 --> 00:22:08.470
we're going to learn how to do
through this entire series.

425
00:22:08.470 --> 00:22:09.340
So it will be really fun.

426
00:22:09.340 --> 00:22:10.910
And we'll see a lot of my cats.

427
00:22:10.910 --> 00:22:11.475
>> Sounds good.

428
00:22:11.475 --> 00:22:13.750
>> [LAUGH] So
if I'm going to run the slide show,

429
00:22:13.750 --> 00:22:15.460
what tab do you think I'm
going to go to on the ribbon.

430
00:22:15.460 --> 00:22:17.070
>> I'm going to say Slideshow.

431
00:22:17.070 --> 00:22:17.660
>> That would be right.

432
00:22:17.660 --> 00:22:18.880
And I was hovering over it wasn't I?

433
00:22:18.880 --> 00:22:21.750
So [LAUGH] gave you a little hint.

434
00:22:21.750 --> 00:22:23.830
So in the slide show I'm
going to go ahead and

435
00:22:23.830 --> 00:22:26.510
run it from the beginning because
that's what I want to do.

436
00:22:26.510 --> 00:22:28.490
And then it goes ahead and
goes into presentation mode.

437
00:22:28.490 --> 00:22:29.000
All right.

438
00:22:29.000 --> 00:22:32.360
So this would be like up on your screen
behind you or wherever you have and

439
00:22:32.360 --> 00:22:34.140
you're gonna say,
let's learn about PowerPoint.

440
00:22:34.140 --> 00:22:36.320
I can introduce myself and
so on and so forth.

441
00:22:36.320 --> 00:22:38.280
How do I go ahead and advance the slide?

442
00:22:38.280 --> 00:22:41.160
There's a lot of ways but for now I'm
just gonna tell you, you just click.

443
00:22:41.160 --> 00:22:43.940
Okay, so we're gonna click with our mouse
and then you can see that we have a text

444
00:22:43.940 --> 00:22:46.940
slide that we can go ahead and
talk about our different bullet points

445
00:22:46.940 --> 00:22:50.250
that we're go over, tables and charts,
and we're gonna talk all about the cats.

446
00:22:50.250 --> 00:22:52.000
We'll probably throw in some
pictures about dogs and

447
00:22:52.000 --> 00:22:57.780
sunsets and flowers to keep it
multifaceted for everybody.

448
00:22:57.780 --> 00:22:59.575
And then we have, these are my stars.

449
00:22:59.575 --> 00:23:01.300
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Meow, meow.

450
00:23:01.300 --> 00:23:02.110
>> Meow, meow, yes.

451
00:23:02.110 --> 00:23:03.484
So this is Fuego and Bishop so

452
00:23:03.484 --> 00:23:06.358
you can see that this is where
I'm adding images to slides.

453
00:23:06.358 --> 00:23:07.657
And then we can compare, so

454
00:23:07.657 --> 00:23:11.200
we have different layouts of how I
want to present the information.

455
00:23:11.200 --> 00:23:14.890
So you can see that Fuego and Bishop, they
are big brother and little brother, and

456
00:23:14.890 --> 00:23:16.420
I would go over each one of these points.

457
00:23:17.980 --> 00:23:19.520
Rolling through this presentation.

458
00:23:19.520 --> 00:23:21.310
>> Right, nice.
>> [LAUGH] We have charts and tables so

459
00:23:21.310 --> 00:23:25.570
you can see that we'll be adding,
well charts and tables, or

460
00:23:25.570 --> 00:23:28.830
I guess I should tables and charts
because I have the table on the left.

461
00:23:28.830 --> 00:23:29.795
>> [LAUGH]
>> Anyways, we'll keep going.

462
00:23:29.795 --> 00:23:33.270
[LAUGH] All right, and
then we're gonna go ahead and

463
00:23:33.270 --> 00:23:35.380
we're gonna add SmartArt
which is kinda fun.

464
00:23:35.380 --> 00:23:36.880
We can have our different diagrams.

465
00:23:36.880 --> 00:23:37.490
>> Nice.
>> Okay, and

466
00:23:37.490 --> 00:23:39.763
you can see that Dad's just the assistant.

467
00:23:39.763 --> 00:23:43.373
[LAUGH] Here,
this is our slide with basic animation.

468
00:23:43.373 --> 00:23:47.525
So as you can see, maybe you noticed that
when you have the slide with all the texts

469
00:23:47.525 --> 00:23:49.496
on it, you read it all, didn't you?

470
00:23:49.496 --> 00:23:50.090
Right?

471
00:23:50.090 --> 00:23:54.840
But I want to control how
the points I want to make come up.

472
00:23:54.840 --> 00:23:58.510
So I can say here we go,
let's talk about this first point and

473
00:23:58.510 --> 00:23:59.760
you're not reading ahead.

474
00:23:59.760 --> 00:24:03.700
So some of these basic animation can be
really helpful on how you can control

475
00:24:03.700 --> 00:24:06.950
the pace of your presentation.

476
00:24:06.950 --> 00:24:10.200
And then another animation because
I forgot what my third point was,

477
00:24:10.200 --> 00:24:13.560
is where another animation that you saw
on that slide was slide transitions.

478
00:24:13.560 --> 00:24:15.902
Get ready.

479
00:24:15.902 --> 00:24:16.474
>> Nice.

480
00:24:16.474 --> 00:24:20.440
>> [LAUGH] Okay,
you probably want to use those sparingly.

481
00:24:20.440 --> 00:24:23.030
That would start to get
a little annoying after awhile.

482
00:24:23.030 --> 00:24:25.540
So you can see that was the transition,
that was the animation,

483
00:24:25.540 --> 00:24:27.710
that was on this particular slide.

484
00:24:27.710 --> 00:24:28.540
And then there we go.

485
00:24:28.540 --> 00:24:29.960
There's my last slide.

486
00:24:29.960 --> 00:24:33.670
And presentations always end where
you can stop on a black screen, so

487
00:24:33.670 --> 00:24:35.200
they don't actually see the last slide.

488
00:24:35.200 --> 00:24:39.100
Whether you wanna stop on the last slide
or on this blank screen, or black screen,

489
00:24:39.100 --> 00:24:40.070
we should say.

490
00:24:40.070 --> 00:24:41.380
You just go ahead and
click one more time, and

491
00:24:41.380 --> 00:24:45.370
then you're back in PowerPoint and
that is the finished product of

492
00:24:45.370 --> 00:24:48.008
all the different things that
we're gonna learn about.

493
00:24:48.008 --> 00:24:51.670
>> All right Vonne, well thank you again
for helping at least to get started.

494
00:24:51.670 --> 00:24:53.750
Taking a look at the environment
that we're gonna be working in,

495
00:24:53.750 --> 00:24:56.110
it's gonna really be helpful learning it,

496
00:24:56.110 --> 00:24:58.380
it's gonna be helpful as you
go throughout this series.

497
00:24:58.380 --> 00:25:01.690
Because instead of you just trying to
guess where Vonne is now clicking,

498
00:25:01.690 --> 00:25:04.730
she's showing you exactly the areas
that you'll be working in.

499
00:25:04.730 --> 00:25:08.690
So that way the time and the learning that
you'll actually spend will be more spent

500
00:25:08.690 --> 00:25:13.280
on those things rather than just I wonder
where Vonne actually meant that to be, or

501
00:25:13.280 --> 00:25:14.860
what did she say, where was that?

502
00:25:14.860 --> 00:25:18.115
She actually kind of lead you through that
as we go throughout the show as well.

503
00:25:18.115 --> 00:25:20.960
Vonne also of course showed us
the way that we can navigate and

504
00:25:20.960 --> 00:25:22.950
be able to look at the presentation area.

505
00:25:22.950 --> 00:25:25.770
And then she showed us how
to run a slideshow as well,

506
00:25:25.770 --> 00:25:28.680
showing us some of those different
things that can be in our slideshow.

507
00:25:28.680 --> 00:25:31.960
And these are all the elements that
we'll be including during this entire

508
00:25:31.960 --> 00:25:33.240
series, too.

509
00:25:33.240 --> 00:25:36.130
So, Vonne, thank you very much for
helping us to get started in

510
00:25:36.130 --> 00:25:40.230
PowerPoint environment, and
thank you also for watching as well.

511
00:25:40.230 --> 00:25:42.980
But this is a great place for
us to end this episode.

512
00:25:42.980 --> 00:25:46.400
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

513
00:25:46.400 --> 00:25:47.520
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

514
00:25:47.520 --> 00:25:51.906
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft PowerPoint 2016 shows.

515
00:25:51.906 --> 00:25:57.503
[MUSIC]

516
00:25:57.503 --> 00:25:59.930
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne show us how to work with PowerPoint slides.  They demonstrate some of the utilities in powerpoint to help us to create slides with slide layouts.  Vonne also shows how to change slide layout, order and add sections.  They discuss the use of sections and of pointer options that show up in PowerPoint 2016
episodes.title: Working with Slides
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:02.586
Welcome to ITPROTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.586 --> 00:00:06.373
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.373 --> 00:00:08.334
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.334 --> 00:00:12.038
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

5
00:00:12.038 --> 00:00:15.170
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITPROTV.

6
00:00:15.170 --> 00:00:20.420
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today
you're watching Microsoft Powerpoint 2016.

7
00:00:20.420 --> 00:00:22.320
We're about to get started
working with slides,

8
00:00:22.320 --> 00:00:25.825
and here to help us out is gonna be our
subject matter expert, Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:25.825 --> 00:00:28.152
Vonne, welcome back to our show,
how are you doing today?

10
00:00:28.152 --> 00:00:29.578
>> Good, thanks for having me back.

11
00:00:29.578 --> 00:00:32.693
>> Well Vonne,
great to have you back on PowerPoint, and

12
00:00:32.693 --> 00:00:35.360
we are ready to start working with slides.

13
00:00:35.360 --> 00:00:36.716
Where are we gonna begin today?

14
00:00:36.716 --> 00:00:42.400
>> So, we're gonna start with just our
basics of selecting and modifying objects.

15
00:00:42.400 --> 00:00:47.378
Now we're going to be adding a lot of
content throughout our slides in all of

16
00:00:47.378 --> 00:00:48.571
these episodes.

17
00:00:48.571 --> 00:00:52.449
So we're just gonna start out with
something really, really basic, just so

18
00:00:52.449 --> 00:00:55.090
I can demonstrate some of the formatting.

19
00:00:55.090 --> 00:00:58.920
Or actually not really formatting, just
the working with the slides in general.

20
00:00:58.920 --> 00:01:02.390
So we're gonna start there, and
then we're gonna move on of adding slides,

21
00:01:02.390 --> 00:01:05.459
deleting slides, and doing all
sorts of fun stuff with our slides.

22
00:01:05.459 --> 00:01:09.900
>> All right Vonne, I understand
that as we start to make PowerPoint

23
00:01:11.440 --> 00:01:13.660
demonstrations that want to be able to do,
or

24
00:01:13.660 --> 00:01:18.310
presentations, the slide is kind of
the basic unit that we're working with.

25
00:01:18.310 --> 00:01:21.586
So, when we actually make them,
are we doing this from scratch?

26
00:01:21.586 --> 00:01:24.310
Or is there something else that
we're actually starting with?

27
00:01:24.310 --> 00:01:25.470
How are we gonna begin?

28
00:01:25.470 --> 00:01:27.990
>> Well, in this episode we're
gonna start from a blank document.

29
00:01:27.990 --> 00:01:31.495
So, I figured just start from the very
beginning, and just dive right in.

30
00:01:31.495 --> 00:01:35.250
So I've actually already got
PowerPoint opened on my computer.

31
00:01:35.250 --> 00:01:37.180
So, we're just gonna start
on the Start screen.

32
00:01:37.180 --> 00:01:40.430
And well, there's blank presentation,
so let's go with blank presentation.

33
00:01:40.430 --> 00:01:43.690
And we're gonna stay working
in blank presentations for

34
00:01:43.690 --> 00:01:46.980
quite a few episodes if you're
watching this in a sequence,

35
00:01:46.980 --> 00:01:49.970
before we get into making them
look really, really pretty.

36
00:01:49.970 --> 00:01:51.540
So, that comes down a little bit later.

37
00:01:51.540 --> 00:01:55.350
So, let's just get our stuff in, learn how
to work with it, and we'll go from there.

38
00:01:55.350 --> 00:01:58.942
So, you can see any time that
you start a blank presentation,

39
00:01:58.942 --> 00:02:02.690
you always start off with
what's called the title slide.

40
00:02:02.690 --> 00:02:09.350
Because every slide has a specific
layout that you can implement to it.

41
00:02:09.350 --> 00:02:11.750
So the default one,
if you're starting from the beginning,

42
00:02:11.750 --> 00:02:14.510
is the title of the presentation.

43
00:02:14.510 --> 00:02:20.260
So that means the default layout of
what they call these placeholder items.

44
00:02:20.260 --> 00:02:24.040
So where it says, we can read that it
says Double tap to add a title, and

45
00:02:24.040 --> 00:02:25.880
Double tap to add a subtitle.

46
00:02:25.880 --> 00:02:29.790
So, this particular layout has
different content boxes, or

47
00:02:29.790 --> 00:02:31.240
like I said, placeholders,

48
00:02:31.240 --> 00:02:37.320
that are kind of guiding you as to this is
what you should put in the title slide.

49
00:02:37.320 --> 00:02:42.053
So we're gonna keep going with what
PowerPoint is suggesting to us,

50
00:02:42.053 --> 00:02:45.903
because I really want to
emphasize mouse cursor icons.

51
00:02:45.903 --> 00:02:50.583
That's probably one of the biggest things
in any Office product to really pay

52
00:02:50.583 --> 00:02:51.527
attention to.

53
00:02:51.527 --> 00:02:54.442
And cuz I've noticed along the years
people are like, well I'm clicking, and

54
00:02:54.442 --> 00:02:55.456
it's not doing anything.

55
00:02:55.456 --> 00:02:57.416
I'm like well,
what does your mouse cursor look like?

56
00:02:57.416 --> 00:02:58.770
And they go I don't know.

57
00:02:58.770 --> 00:03:00.460
Well that actually makes a big difference,

58
00:03:00.460 --> 00:03:02.880
because that indicates what
you're gonna do, all right?

59
00:03:02.880 --> 00:03:07.460
So, if I'm out here, so
I'm out like kind of in the blank area.

60
00:03:07.460 --> 00:03:10.050
You can see that I have
a basic white arrow.

61
00:03:10.050 --> 00:03:12.740
That means it doesn't really
mean much of anything.

62
00:03:12.740 --> 00:03:14.408
Okay?
It just means that if I click,

63
00:03:14.408 --> 00:03:15.852
it's not gonna do anything.

64
00:03:15.852 --> 00:03:22.220
But if I move my mouse into that content
area, you see my mouse turns to an I beam.

65
00:03:22.220 --> 00:03:25.320
An I beam always means text.

66
00:03:25.320 --> 00:03:30.464
So if I were to click right now,
it would start and do text, okay?

67
00:03:30.464 --> 00:03:35.641
Around those edges of those place holder
or content boxes, my mouse turns into

68
00:03:35.641 --> 00:03:40.599
a four pointed arrow with an arrow on
top of it, with a regular white arrow.

69
00:03:40.599 --> 00:03:44.760
That indicates that you would be
able to move that content area.

70
00:03:46.570 --> 00:03:47.640
And here, I'm gonna zoom in for you.

71
00:03:47.640 --> 00:03:49.420
So if you're in this little area,

72
00:03:49.420 --> 00:03:52.960
if I just move a little bit further up,
there's my white arrow.

73
00:03:52.960 --> 00:03:56.480
Little down, there's my four point arrow,
little bit further down, I beam.

74
00:03:56.480 --> 00:04:00.810
So you can see in a very,
very small space, it can turn into

75
00:04:00.810 --> 00:04:04.750
three different mouse cursor icons that
do three completely different things.

76
00:04:04.750 --> 00:04:06.418
So just always be aware of it.

77
00:04:06.418 --> 00:04:12.130
I always tell people, slow down, take
a breath, see what you're doing, okay?

78
00:04:12.130 --> 00:04:13.913
So, we're going to get out of zoom.

79
00:04:13.913 --> 00:04:17.814
And with my I beam, I'm just gonna click
and you can see that it activates that

80
00:04:17.814 --> 00:04:21.958
particular placeholder, and it allows me
to type in, cuz I've got that flashing

81
00:04:21.958 --> 00:04:25.360
cursor that says add text so
I'm just gonna say Hello, for there.

82
00:04:25.360 --> 00:04:27.890
All right, perfect.

83
00:04:27.890 --> 00:04:33.290
Throughout any of these Office shows, now
specifically since we're doing PowerPoint,

84
00:04:33.290 --> 00:04:36.210
you'll probably hear me say
a lot about just click off it,

85
00:04:36.210 --> 00:04:39.190
like just get out of it, just stop it.

86
00:04:39.190 --> 00:04:41.430
That means just find
that white arrow again.

87
00:04:41.430 --> 00:04:42.530
Just find a blank space.

88
00:04:42.530 --> 00:04:47.160
And if I click it, do you see how then it
deactivates that area that I was just in,

89
00:04:47.160 --> 00:04:51.370
and now I'm just,
I don't have anything selected, okay?

90
00:04:51.370 --> 00:04:55.778
So if I go ahead and
click to add a subtitle, we'll just say,

91
00:04:55.778 --> 00:04:57.862
what should I say, Ronnie?

92
00:04:57.862 --> 00:04:59.780
>> Say welcome to PowerPoint.

93
00:04:59.780 --> 00:05:01.192
>> Okay, there we go [LAUGH].

94
00:05:01.192 --> 00:05:01.882
Had a little like.

95
00:05:01.882 --> 00:05:03.468
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hm, what am I suppose to say?

96
00:05:03.468 --> 00:05:05.235
[LAUGH].
So let's go ahead and say,

97
00:05:05.235 --> 00:05:07.200
well Hello Welcome to PowerPoint.

98
00:05:07.200 --> 00:05:09.101
Perfect, that goes well together.

99
00:05:09.101 --> 00:05:11.548
All right, so I'm gonna click off,
find my white arrow.

100
00:05:11.548 --> 00:05:16.040
But notice, see if I move my,
I didn't click off, just to show you that

101
00:05:16.040 --> 00:05:20.160
if I had gone a little bit further up,
thinking I'm clicking off,

102
00:05:20.160 --> 00:05:24.830
but I'm actually putting my I-beam
back in that other placeholder area.

103
00:05:24.830 --> 00:05:28.730
So just notice that right out here,
you don't think you're

104
00:05:28.730 --> 00:05:33.660
anywhere in an area that's in that
content area, but you are, okay?

105
00:05:33.660 --> 00:05:36.680
So, watch those mouse cursors,
very, very important.

106
00:05:36.680 --> 00:05:40.640
And notice once I've actually put content
into those place holders, those little

107
00:05:40.640 --> 00:05:45.590
dotted lines that were indicating to
me this is a space that you can occupy.

108
00:05:45.590 --> 00:05:46.500
They're gone now.

109
00:05:46.500 --> 00:05:49.780
Well, that's because we
filled that area in, so

110
00:05:49.780 --> 00:05:54.030
now I don't see those guidelines,
if you want to say.

111
00:05:54.030 --> 00:05:57.610
>> So Vonne, starting off with the idea
of what you did there, where you

112
00:05:57.610 --> 00:06:00.940
clicked on that blank presentation right
at the beginning, is really beginning with

113
00:06:00.940 --> 00:06:03.370
a template which says,
here's how we think you should begin.

114
00:06:03.370 --> 00:06:08.290
And this is very helpful because you
may not exactly know where to begin and

115
00:06:08.290 --> 00:06:09.210
what to begin doing.

116
00:06:09.210 --> 00:06:12.840
So by doing this and having those
particular placeholders in place,

117
00:06:12.840 --> 00:06:16.370
ready to go, it at least gets
you a start in what you can do.

118
00:06:16.370 --> 00:06:20.540
Now, Vonne, I know I wanna create
a presentation, but I only have one slide.

119
00:06:20.540 --> 00:06:22.310
Is that gonna be my whole presentation?

120
00:06:22.310 --> 00:06:23.371
What do I need to do next?

121
00:06:23.371 --> 00:06:27.517
>> Well, I mean, I guess you could start
with one slide, but I'd have to say a lot.

122
00:06:27.517 --> 00:06:28.390
And [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

123
00:06:28.390 --> 00:06:29.271
>> If we're just doing like a ten

124
00:06:29.271 --> 00:06:31.505
minute presentation, or a ten second
presentation, that might be good.

125
00:06:31.505 --> 00:06:34.074
But yeah,
we probably wanna add some slides in here.

126
00:06:34.074 --> 00:06:36.175
So how do we do that?

127
00:06:36.175 --> 00:06:38.580
There's a couple of different ways.

128
00:06:38.580 --> 00:06:41.460
I think, right here on the Home
tab that says New slide,

129
00:06:41.460 --> 00:06:43.930
that's a nice indication that
I would like a new slide.

130
00:06:43.930 --> 00:06:45.735
Now, two things to point out.

131

of this place holder content box.

353
00:18:56.840 --> 00:18:59.920
All right, I'm gonna go over
to the four pointed arrow.

354
00:18:59.920 --> 00:19:02.200
Cuz remember four point
arrow means two things.

355
00:19:02.200 --> 00:19:07.770
It's going to mean move but it also means
that I want to select the whole box,

356
00:19:07.770 --> 00:19:10.750
not the I beam where I'm
going in to select the text.

357
00:19:10.750 --> 00:19:12.080
So if I click here,

358
00:19:12.080 --> 00:19:16.380
I've selected this content area and
I'm just gonna resize this for now.

359
00:19:16.380 --> 00:19:20.230
Maybe move it around, and then I'm gonna
click here, and that's just with the two

360
00:19:20.230 --> 00:19:23.700
pointer arrows, which we'll cover more,
and I'm gonna move it over here.

361
00:19:23.700 --> 00:19:26.420
So I have changed the slide.

362
00:19:26.420 --> 00:19:31.134
But that's not looking so
great as, well it's not that great.

363
00:19:31.134 --> 00:19:35.760
[LAUGH] So I want to reset this slide.

364
00:19:35.760 --> 00:19:37.120
Well let's click and
see what that button does.

365
00:19:38.420 --> 00:19:40.790
It did exactly that,
it did not delete my content.

366
00:19:40.790 --> 00:19:44.839
It reset the slide to any
formatting that you had done and

367
00:19:44.839 --> 00:19:47.855
set it back to the default positioning and

368
00:19:47.855 --> 00:19:52.542
placement of those placeholder boxes so
it can be really handy.

369
00:19:52.542 --> 00:19:56.670
It's like let's start over,
but not completely over.

370
00:19:56.670 --> 00:19:58.350
I'm not deleting anything.

371
00:19:58.350 --> 00:20:02.460
I'm just putting the slide back
to the way it was by default,

372
00:20:02.460 --> 00:20:06.470
which can be very, very handy,
so I like that one.

373
00:20:06.470 --> 00:20:09.480
And the last little button
that's in this slides

374
00:20:09.480 --> 00:20:13.090
group within the home tab
is this little button.

375
00:20:13.090 --> 00:20:16.000
This is our section, so
sections are really just for

376
00:20:16.000 --> 00:20:20.567
you to mark different areas of your slide
presentation of like well this is the time

377
00:20:20.567 --> 00:20:22.633
where I'm gonna talk about my cats.

378
00:20:22.633 --> 00:20:26.670
And this is gonna be the slides that
cover sunsets or what have you.

379
00:20:26.670 --> 00:20:30.649
I'm on slide one, so if I click on
Add Section, notice that you do have

380
00:20:30.649 --> 00:20:35.168
to make one consideration of like where do
I want to be when I add this section, so

381
00:20:35.168 --> 00:20:37.810
always think about that first.

382
00:20:37.810 --> 00:20:39.974
I'm on slide one, so
I'll add a section and

383
00:20:39.974 --> 00:20:42.617
I'm gonna say here we go
here is an untitled section.

384
00:20:42.617 --> 00:20:46.539
It just automatically added it to that and
on top of,

385
00:20:46.539 --> 00:20:50.600
on the front of the slide
that I had selected.

386
00:20:50.600 --> 00:20:52.860
Notice that it does,
when I click on the section name,

387
00:20:52.860 --> 00:20:54.660
it highlights all the slides.

388
00:20:54.660 --> 00:20:58.390
Cuz maybe I want to format
all of these slides at once.

389
00:20:58.390 --> 00:21:00.860
Maybe make different changes
to the font or what have you.

390
00:21:00.860 --> 00:21:04.440
So that's another nice thing about adding
sections is it's a quick way to select

391
00:21:04.440 --> 00:21:06.600
multiple slides at once.

392
00:21:06.600 --> 00:21:09.060
But untitled is not very descriptive.

393
00:21:09.060 --> 00:21:13.240
So if you right-click on that untitled
section, you can then rename it.

394
00:21:14.340 --> 00:21:15.928
So we can say Beginning.

395
00:21:15.928 --> 00:21:17.432
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

396
00:21:17.432 --> 00:21:19.610
>> That sounds like a good one.

397
00:21:19.610 --> 00:21:21.550
All right, so
now I have the beginning section.

398
00:21:21.550 --> 00:21:26.490
And maybe starting at slide three,
it's going to start a new section.

399
00:21:26.490 --> 00:21:30.360
So you could also
right-click on this slide.

400
00:21:30.360 --> 00:21:33.470
So we can go ahead and say Add a Section,
and then it adds it, but

401
00:21:33.470 --> 00:21:38.560
then we have to back,
right-click on the section and rename it.

402
00:21:38.560 --> 00:21:39.910
So then we'll name this 3.

403
00:21:39.910 --> 00:21:43.176
Because I can't think of anything
else creatively to name it.

404
00:21:43.176 --> 00:21:48.048
So now I have these different sections
which can be really great for

405
00:21:48.048 --> 00:21:50.150
organizing it.

406
00:21:50.150 --> 00:21:53.575
And then if you ever wanted for
some reason to delete the section,

407
00:21:53.575 --> 00:21:56.076
like that's just not working or
what have you.

408
00:21:56.076 --> 00:22:00.819
You can then notice that you can remove
the section, but now, remove the section

409
00:22:00.819 --> 00:22:04.750
and the slides, you might not
wanna do that, well, maybe you do.

410
00:22:04.750 --> 00:22:06.320
But at least it gives you that option,
okay?

411
00:22:06.320 --> 00:22:11.350
So it's just organizing slides
into sections that you can do.

412
00:22:11.350 --> 00:22:12.570
You can also collapse.

413
00:22:12.570 --> 00:22:16.560
Think about if you had ten slides in one
section and ten slides in another and

414
00:22:16.560 --> 00:22:20.270
you realized all those ten slides need
to go in front of these ten slides.

415
00:22:20.270 --> 00:22:24.952
That's a nice way to where you could
collapse them down and then you can drag

416
00:22:24.952 --> 00:22:29.187
and drop your sections the same way
that you were resorting slides,

417
00:22:29.187 --> 00:22:30.841
you can resort sections.

418
00:22:30.841 --> 00:22:34.916
So think about moving large chunks
of multiple slides at one time,

419
00:22:34.916 --> 00:22:39.140
that can be way easier than moving
in all the individual slides.

420
00:22:39.140 --> 00:22:42.150
So that can be really,
really handy and I think

421
00:22:42.150 --> 00:22:46.850
that's a great way to organize your
slides and a great place to stop, maybe.

422
00:22:46.850 --> 00:22:51.270
>> Yeah, the idea of using sections
really does seem very powerful.

423
00:22:51.270 --> 00:22:55.470
Such as if you just wanted to show a
portion as well during your presentation,

424
00:22:55.470 --> 00:23:01.740
which I'm pretty sure Vonne will
get a little bit later on as well.

425
00:23:01.740 --> 00:23:04.310
Where instead, you can kind of
create a custom slide show and

426
00:23:04.310 --> 00:23:05.510
just name that section.

427
00:23:05.510 --> 00:23:08.900
And be able to only show those without
having to delete everything out, and

428
00:23:08.900 --> 00:23:10.620
do everything that you need to as well.

429
00:23:10.620 --> 00:23:14.080
So, the idea of working with
multiple slides is very important,

430
00:23:14.080 --> 00:23:17.170
because most slide shows are not
gonna be just a single slide.

431
00:23:17.170 --> 00:23:20.020
The great thing is PowerPoint
helps us out by providing

432
00:23:20.020 --> 00:23:23.200
the ability to add in those
content sections that we need to.

433
00:23:23.200 --> 00:23:24.550
To help us get started.

434
00:23:24.550 --> 00:23:26.100
A lot of times it's very difficult.

435
00:23:26.100 --> 00:23:29.351
It's intimidating to get started
with just a blank piece of paper or

436
00:23:29.351 --> 00:23:31.930
a blank slide and go all right,
make a presentation.

437
00:23:31.930 --> 00:23:34.840
But by helping us out we know exactly
what we need to add in and maybe at

438
00:23:34.840 --> 00:23:38.212
that point our creativity will begin to
flow or our content will begin to flow or

439
00:23:38.212 --> 00:23:41.245
our content will begin to flow
the way that we need to as well.

440
00:23:41.245 --> 00:23:43.030
Vonne has just demonstrated,
of course then,

441
00:23:43.030 --> 00:23:47.470
how do we get that into PowerPoint and
then we can see how to manipulate that and

442
00:23:47.470 --> 00:23:51.190
change it around in what's going to make
a very effective PowerPoint presentation.

443
00:23:51.190 --> 00:23:53.430
So Vonne, thank you again for
helping us out here.

444
00:23:53.430 --> 00:23:55.720
And thank you also for watching.

445
00:23:55.720 --> 00:23:58.260
This is a great place for
us to sign off then.

446
00:23:58.260 --> 00:24:00.830
For ITPRO.TV I've been
your host Ronnie Wong.

447
00:24:00.830 --> 00:24:01.920
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

448
00:24:01.920 --> 00:24:05.670
>> Stay tuned right here for
more on Microsoft PowerPoint 2016 shows.

449
00:24:05.670 --> 00:24:12.750
[MUSIC]

450
00:24:12.750 --> 00:24:14.139
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne showed how to work with text and features that help us work with text in PowerPoint 2016.  Vonne demonstrated the PowerPoint helps when you begin to type text and setup slides.  She demonstrated  how it helps us to autosize and the AutoCorrect features.  Lastlly, the discussed and showed how to change the autocorrect options within PowerPoint.
episodes.title: Working with Text
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:06.673
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.673 --> 00:00:08.419
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.419 --> 00:00:12.241
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.241 --> 00:00:15.313
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV,

5
00:00:15.313 --> 00:00:16.980
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:16.980 --> 00:00:20.576
And today you're watching
Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

7
00:00:20.576 --> 00:00:23.119
And here to help us out is
going to be Miss Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:23.119 --> 00:00:26.409
As she helps us to get
started in working with text.

9
00:00:26.409 --> 00:00:31.117
Vonne, where are we going to begin today
when we take a look at working with text?

10
00:00:31.117 --> 00:00:33.856
>> We're going to be adding
them into our slides.

11
00:00:33.856 --> 00:00:37.760
So [LAUGH] we're gonna add our
content into our placeholder text.

12
00:00:37.760 --> 00:00:43.390
We're going to go over adding our lists,
because when we're giving a presentation,

13
00:00:43.390 --> 00:00:46.130
we don't always want to
put in full paragraphs.

14
00:00:46.130 --> 00:00:49.720
Now I think every slide show has
it's purpose and it's place and

15
00:00:49.720 --> 00:00:52.610
it's audience for
what you're trying to do.

16
00:00:52.610 --> 00:00:57.060
But large amounts of text, you probably
aren't gonna necessarily add to a slide.

17
00:00:57.060 --> 00:01:00.450
So a lot of it you want to display
it like your main points in there.

18
00:01:00.450 --> 00:01:03.860
So is going to be in usually
a form of a bulleted list.

19
00:01:03.860 --> 00:01:07.120
So we're going to go over
adding the text to a list.

20
00:01:07.120 --> 00:01:11.838
We're also going to do some fun stuff with
auto correct options and some spelling and

21
00:01:11.838 --> 00:01:13.640
it's gonna be a grand old time.

22
00:01:13.640 --> 00:01:15.370
So and I might need you help there Ronnie,

23
00:01:15.370 --> 00:01:17.446
because I'm gonna need
a add some information and

24
00:01:17.446 --> 00:01:20.376
I'm going to need your help of what
we're gonna actually talk about.

25
00:01:20.376 --> 00:01:23.347
[LAUGH]
>> That sounds good Vonne, so

26
00:01:23.347 --> 00:01:28.870
if we start taking a look then if if we
want to begin our PowerPoint correctly.

27
00:01:28.870 --> 00:01:30.990
We do, we need to at least pick a subject,
right?

28
00:01:30.990 --> 00:01:33.866
So, let's let's think about
what we want to talk about.

29
00:01:33.866 --> 00:01:36.578
Vonne I know that you like cats,

30
00:01:36.578 --> 00:01:41.610
I know that you like hockey,
I know that you like boy bands.

31
00:01:41.610 --> 00:01:44.499
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'm gonna put my vote in for cats or

32
00:01:44.499 --> 00:01:49.417
hockey, but Vonne, I'll let you
make the ultimate decision here.

33
00:01:49.417 --> 00:01:50.734
>> Well, you know what?

34
00:01:50.734 --> 00:01:52.191
We should probably talk about cats.

35
00:01:52.191 --> 00:01:55.125
When I start talking about hockey
I might get a little animated and

36
00:01:55.125 --> 00:01:57.967
a little spirited and
who knows what's gonna come flying out.

37
00:01:57.967 --> 00:01:58.773
>> Yeah.

38
00:01:58.773 --> 00:01:59.848
>> Let's talk about cats.

39
00:01:59.848 --> 00:02:02.724
>> Okay, yeah, if this is about boy bands
we know that you're definitely gonna get

40
00:02:02.724 --> 00:02:03.456
animated there so.

41
00:02:03.456 --> 00:02:07.019
So let's go ahead and
let's use the idea of cats here.

42
00:02:07.019 --> 00:02:10.969
[CROSSTALK] All right Vonne so
where are we gonna begin?

43
00:02:10.969 --> 00:02:15.240
>> Awesome, so I actually have a slide
show already started, or a presentation.

44
00:02:15.240 --> 00:02:17.150
I just started a new blank slide.

45
00:02:17.150 --> 00:02:19.160
So we're going to tap to add a title.

46
00:02:19.160 --> 00:02:20.560
Cuz we did go over that already.

47
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:22.545
We're just going to click it and type it.

48
00:02:22.545 --> 00:02:24.403
So we're gonna type Cats.

49
00:02:24.403 --> 00:02:25.249
>> Cats.

50
00:02:25.249 --> 00:02:26.461
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's real original, I like it.

51
00:02:26.461 --> 00:02:27.074
>> Right?

52
00:02:27.074 --> 00:02:30.564
And we're going to just say.

53
00:02:30.564 --> 00:02:32.242
>> My cats?

54
00:02:32.242 --> 00:02:33.076
Vonne's cats.

55
00:02:33.076 --> 00:02:34.363
>> We're gonna say Vonne and Ronnie.

56
00:02:34.363 --> 00:02:35.417
>> There we go, we're cats now, great.

57
00:02:35.417 --> 00:02:36.335
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

58
00:02:36.335 --> 00:02:41.131
So just to point out really
quickly that red squiggly?

59
00:02:41.131 --> 00:02:42.014
>> Yes.

60
00:02:42.014 --> 00:02:43.069
>> All right.

61
00:02:43.069 --> 00:02:43.573
>> Yeah.

62
00:02:43.573 --> 00:02:44.333
>> The program likes you.

63
00:02:44.333 --> 00:02:46.527
It doesn't like me too much, right?

64
00:02:46.527 --> 00:02:48.965
That just indicates I have
a misspelled word, and

65
00:02:48.965 --> 00:02:51.062
that's always gonna happen with my name.

66
00:02:51.062 --> 00:02:54.478
[LAUGH] But we'll get back to
what that means how we can fix it

67
00:02:54.478 --> 00:02:59.038
after we add another slide and start
getting some more information about it.

68
00:02:59.038 --> 00:03:02.613
All right, so let's go ahead and
add a slide I'm going to add a title and

69
00:03:02.613 --> 00:03:06.260
content and I'm just using that drop
down so you can see what I'm doing.

70
00:03:06.260 --> 00:03:07.450
So here we go.

71
00:03:07.450 --> 00:03:08.574
And we're gonna add a title.

72
00:03:08.574 --> 00:03:11.060
What should the title of this slide be,
Ronnie?

73
00:03:11.060 --> 00:03:16.094
>> [LAUGH] Since we're talking about
cats here, and it's about you and me.

74
00:03:16.094 --> 00:03:17.795
We have a couple of choices, right?

75
00:03:17.795 --> 00:03:21.677
We can either do a group
thing about the owners, or

76
00:03:21.677 --> 00:03:27.977
we can talk about the environment that
the cats are in, which one would you like?

77
00:03:27.977 --> 00:03:30.605
>> How about we do our cats,
because I'm sure we've probably had

78
00:03:30.605 --> 00:03:32.745
a couple iterations of
cats throughout the years.

79
00:03:32.745 --> 00:03:37.953
[LAUGH] So we'll say Our Cats,
all right, so I've added our title.

80
00:03:37.953 --> 00:03:41.101
All right, so
I'm gonna click here to add my text.

81
00:03:41.101 --> 00:03:45.617
And notice as soon as I click in here,
it's kinda gray, but there is a bullet

82
00:03:45.617 --> 00:03:50.920
point there, so we're actually going
to be doing or starting our list, okay?

83
00:03:50.920 --> 00:03:57.720
So I'm just gonna make up something like,
let's

84
00:03:57.720 --> 00:04:02.730
talk about, now you're all watching me
type, and I'm not gonna type right at all.

85
00:04:02.730 --> 00:04:05.110
Let's talk about cats, all right.

86
00:04:05.110 --> 00:04:06.556
Just to get that first bullet point in.

87
00:04:06.556 --> 00:04:10.867
Now if I Enter,
I'm making another bullet point.

88
00:04:10.867 --> 00:04:14.679
So I have to say let's have a new
paragraph, because I am hitting Enter.

89
00:04:14.679 --> 00:04:16.546
So, what I'd like to do.

90
00:04:16.546 --> 00:04:21.589
Why don't we go ahead and I'll talk
about my cats first, and then we'll talk

91
00:04:21.589 --> 00:04:26.420
about yours, because that way we can
show our different levels of lists.

92
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:29.498
So I'm just gonna go ahead and
put my name in there.

93
00:04:29.498 --> 00:04:30.970
Now, I wanna go ahead and

94
00:04:30.970 --> 00:04:34.344
go through the different names
of my cats that I have had.

95
00:04:34.344 --> 00:04:35.267
>> Okay.

96
00:04:35.267 --> 00:04:38.125
>> But if I hit Enter it's
on the same level, right?

97
00:04:38.125 --> 00:04:39.123
>> Right.

98
00:04:39.123 --> 00:04:41.851
>> But I want to say, well,
the cats that I've had.

99
00:04:41.851 --> 00:04:43.429
So they need to be underneath me.

100
00:04:43.429 --> 00:04:46.906
If you wanna say, so
that's where you can indent.

101
00:04:46.906 --> 00:04:47.979
Well, it's not actually indenting.

102
00:04:47.979 --> 00:04:50.115
It's demoting, right?

103
00:04:50.115 --> 00:04:51.422
Yeah, we're indenting.

104
00:04:51.422 --> 00:04:54.982
We making, I call it a sublist.

105
00:04:54.982 --> 00:04:58.804
Okay, so the easiest way to do
this is to hit the Tab key.

106
00:04:58.804 --> 00:05:03.678
If you hit the Tab key, you see how it
goes ahead and indents my bullet level.

107
00:05:03.678 --> 00:05:06.051
I think that's the easiest way to do it.

108
00:05:06.051 --> 00:05:09.809
You can always come up to these
different increase and decrease.

109
00:05:09.809 --> 00:05:10.707
That's what they call them.

110
00:05:10.707 --> 00:05:11.746
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

111
00:05:11.746 --> 00:05:14.509
you can see that if I hit the decrease,
it's going to go back out.

112
00:05:14.509 --> 00:05:15.834
If I hit the increase.

113
00:05:15.834 --> 00:05:18.349
But while I'm typing,
I just think it's easier for

114
00:05:18.349 --> 00:05:19.957
me to just keep on going, right?

115
00:05:19.957 --> 00:05:25.828
So let's go with my current cats, which
are Fuego, okay, that's the first one.

116
00:05:25.828 --> 00:05:30.098
Now notice since I am indented in
this sub list, if I hit Enter,

117
00:05:30.098 --> 00:05:32.932
it's going to keep me on that same level.

118
00:05:32.932 --> 00:05:35.771
So then I could go ahead and
type in Bishop.

119
00:05:35.771 --> 00:05:37.487
Those are my two cats, okay?

120
00:05:37.487 --> 00:05:38.488
>> All right.

121
00:05:38.488 --> 00:05:41.864
>> Now if I hit Enter again,
I'm still on that same level.

122
00:05:41.864 --> 00:05:46.345
But what I'd really like to do is add a
new main topic, which would be your cats.

123
00:05:46.345 --> 00:05:47.306
>> Okay.

124
00:05:47.306 --> 00:05:49.690
>> So I wanna type in Ronnie, but
I don't want to be in this area.

125
00:05:49.690 --> 00:05:53.870
So if I can tab to get in,
Shift+Tab is how you can get out.

126
00:05:53.870 --> 00:05:57.250
So again, since I'm already typing,
I'm gonna throw you out those shortcuts.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne continue working with text in PowerPoint 2016.  They demonstrate some of the different options for getting text into PowerPoint without having to manually type text.  They talk about and show cut, copy and paste options, as well as selecting texts and using find and replace to help Powerpoint users put text where they want it to go!

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne take a look at formatting text in PowerPoint 2016.  They differentiate how to apply character formatting and paragraph formatting.  Vonne displays selecting fonts, size and color.   They discuss the use of bullets and colors for the effect that we can create on the powerpoint.  Lastly, they demonstrate that formatting the speaker notes show up in the notes view but not in the normal view.
episodes.title: Formatting Text
