00:23:09.110 --> 00:23:11.010
notice that it's red text and everything.

419
00:23:12.380 --> 00:23:18.110
I'm gonna dip my paint brush into this
paint, so I've got where I want to copy.

420
00:23:18.110 --> 00:23:20.490
I click the format painter, and

421
00:23:20.490 --> 00:23:24.875
my mouse cursor icon turns into
an I beam with a paint brush on it.

422
00:23:24.875 --> 00:23:29.250
Then I go ahead and
paint over what I want to take,

423
00:23:29.250 --> 00:23:32.200
and do you see how, or
want to copy to really.

424
00:23:32.200 --> 00:23:37.390
And you see that it took
the formatting of where I had said,

425
00:23:37.390 --> 00:23:39.740
now make the painter, and
it brings it over here.

426
00:23:39.740 --> 00:23:41.820
It's kind of like copy and
paste formatting.

427
00:23:41.820 --> 00:23:43.060
Okay?

428
00:23:43.060 --> 00:23:48.950
So that could be really helpful, but
the one thing is it's that one time only.

429
00:23:48.950 --> 00:23:50.530
It's like then okay I'm done.

430
00:23:50.530 --> 00:23:52.979
Right?

431
00:23:52.979 --> 00:23:56.189
My analogy was instead of taking a paint
brush you would paint the wall you can

432
00:23:56.189 --> 00:23:59.517
take the spray gun, right, where you can
just [SOUND], just spray like crazy.

433
00:23:59.517 --> 00:24:02.336
That's the kind of analogy
that I would always use.

434
00:24:02.336 --> 00:24:06.284
We can go back and get the formatting
of where you want to originate and

435
00:24:06.284 --> 00:24:09.140
you can double click the format painter.

436
00:24:09.140 --> 00:24:13.910
If you double click the format painter
it's like keeping the spray gun on.

437
00:24:13.910 --> 00:24:18.120
So if I quickly double click the format
painter, you see I can go ahead and

438
00:24:18.120 --> 00:24:19.770
paint over here.

439
00:24:19.770 --> 00:24:25.568
Paint over here, paint over here, and
I can keep on selecting and painting.

440
00:24:25.568 --> 00:24:29.530
Now the thing is, it's kinda like if
the button's on, how do I turn it off?

441
00:24:29.530 --> 00:24:33.190
Cuz now you're like, no, stop, no,
no, no, no wait I'm done right?

442
00:24:33.190 --> 00:24:37.270
You have to turn the gun off,
or turn the spray thing off.

443
00:24:37.270 --> 00:24:40.456
So you come over here to the format
painter you click it off.

444
00:24:40.456 --> 00:24:43.921
And now you're back to the regular
I Beam where you can go ahead and

445
00:24:43.921 --> 00:24:46.010
control how you want to do everything.

446
00:24:46.010 --> 00:24:49.287
So the format panel it's pretty handy,
I do like it a lot.

447
00:24:49.287 --> 00:24:53.703
>> Vonne, I've used the format painter
over and over again, because what's end up

448
00:24:53.703 --> 00:24:57.288
happening sometimes is I inherited
PowerPoint presentations and

449
00:24:57.288 --> 00:25:01.820
I knew I needed to insert a new slide
with different things that were in it.

450
00:25:01.820 --> 00:25:05.560
So, the problem is I didn't know what
the user that previously created it,

451
00:25:05.560 --> 00:25:08.350
I didn't know what font they chose,
I didn't know the size,

452
00:25:08.350 --> 00:25:10.190
I didn't know the specific color.

453
00:25:10.190 --> 00:25:13.705
I didn't know any of that, so it was
multiple levels of formatting and then if

454
00:25:13.705 --> 00:25:17.329
I we're to try manually create it then I
have not going search through the font,

455
00:25:17.329 --> 00:25:19.792
figure out the actual size,
put in the actual color.

456
00:25:19.792 --> 00:25:23.470
But by using this format painter I
can put in there the default size and

457
00:25:23.470 --> 00:25:26.199
then just now copy that
formatting paste it over and

458
00:25:26.199 --> 00:25:28.750
then I don't have to go
through all that again.

459
00:25:28.750 --> 00:25:32.152
So it really can help save time, and
it can help you in a mess when you're not

460
00:25:32.152 --> 00:25:35.508
exactly sure and you have to produce
as something like that very quickly.

461
00:25:35.508 --> 00:25:39.712
So I've seen it work very much so
and it's really an incredible thing.

462
00:25:39.712 --> 00:25:42.193
>> Exactly, and along those same lines,

463
00:25:42.193 --> 00:25:47.530
sometimes I always want to take everything
off of what they did and just start over.

464
00:25:47.530 --> 00:25:51.820
Can I just get back to the basics and
then, I'll apply the colors as I want?

465
00:25:51.820 --> 00:25:57.019
That's actually a good lead-in to what I
wanted to show you is the reset button,

466
00:25:57.019 --> 00:25:59.243
the clear all formatting, okay?

467
00:25:59.243 --> 00:26:03.117
So I can take this text,
I can select everything that I wanna say,

468
00:26:03.117 --> 00:26:05.940
take the font, the color, all of that.

469
00:26:05.940 --> 00:26:08.398
I click on this little button right here,
and you see I forgot.

470
00:26:08.398 --> 00:26:10.659
I just realized it's not
gonna take off the bullets,

471
00:26:10.659 --> 00:26:12.930
because that's a paragraph
level formatting.

472
00:26:12.930 --> 00:26:18.540
But it will at least remove the,
all of the font yes,

473
00:26:18.540 --> 00:26:20.080
the character formatting, thank you.

474
00:26:20.080 --> 00:26:22.900
And then I could go back and
reset my bullets, I could go to none and

475
00:26:22.900 --> 00:26:24.810
then I could apply
everything like that way.

476
00:26:24.810 --> 00:26:27.560
But you will have to reset some
of the paragraph options, and

477
00:26:27.560 --> 00:26:29.910
that's kind of nice.

478
00:26:29.910 --> 00:26:31.230
I do like that button as well.

479
00:26:31.230 --> 00:26:33.184
One last thing on the paragraph
level formatting,

480
00:26:33.184 --> 00:26:35.737
cuz you can see we talked about
a lot of these other things besides.

481
00:26:35.737 --> 00:26:39.261
But the only thing we didn't
talk about is line spacing, so

482
00:26:39.261 --> 00:26:41.948
line spacing that's something right here.

483
00:26:41.948 --> 00:26:44.321
That's not it that's the column sorry.

484
00:26:44.321 --> 00:26:45.714
[LAUGH] One more button up.

485
00:26:45.714 --> 00:26:48.170
There's our line spacing.

486
00:26:48.170 --> 00:26:52.826
And you could see that with here if
I wanted to add more space between

487
00:26:52.826 --> 00:26:57.661
the lines you can do the first one's
which are just the line spacing.

488
00:26:57.661 --> 00:27:00.350
And it looks like it's
spacing everything out.

489
00:27:00.350 --> 00:27:05.230
But I did wanna point out on another
slide some of the differences between

490
00:27:05.230 --> 00:27:09.397
the format, the space after paragraph and
the line spacing.

491
00:27:09.397 --> 00:27:11.920
So here we have two paragraphs.

492
00:27:11.920 --> 00:27:14.940
This is one paragraph,
this is another paragraph okay?

493
00:27:14.940 --> 00:27:18.700
If I selected all of this text and

494
00:27:18.700 --> 00:27:22.780
I come over here to our line spacing and
I start doing the line spacing.

495
00:27:22.780 --> 00:27:27.540
You see, it's adding the spaces between
all of the lines of the paragraphs.

496
00:27:27.540 --> 00:27:31.770
But I really wanted a space
between here and here, like after

497
00:27:31.770 --> 00:27:36.700
each paragraph especially if you have
bullets that span across two lines.

498
00:27:36.700 --> 00:27:39.320
You don't wanna add it between
the lines of the bullets,

499
00:27:39.320 --> 00:27:43.000
you wanna say after each bullet or
after each paragraph.

500
00:27:43.000 --> 00:27:45.940
That is space after paragraph.

501
00:27:45.940 --> 00:27:47.531
So if I selected this, I only have two so

502
00:27:47.531 --> 00:27:50.681
if I had a couple more I think it would
make a little bit better demonstration.

503
00:27:50.681 --> 00:27:55.290
If I go into line spacing options,
it's right here.

504
00:27:55.290 --> 00:27:57.490
Space, before and after.

505
00:27:57.490 --> 00:28:00.320
I don't usually like to
keep the before space.

506
00:28:00.320 --> 00:28:03.265
I always think of, like,
when you're going down, it's always after.

507
00:28:03.265 --> 00:28:06.900
Cuz if you double up the before and after,
you're actually the doubling the space and

508
00:28:06.900 --> 00:28:08.050
it can be a little confusing.

509
00:28:08.050 --> 00:28:09.590
So I'm just gonna go ahead,
and put that to 0.

510
00:28:09.590 --> 00:28:14.390
I'm gonna bump this up to 12,
and I'm gonna click, okay.

511
00:28:14.390 --> 00:28:16.500
That was not enough to
make a big difference.

512
00:28:16.500 --> 00:28:18.436
Let's go ahead and make that 24.

513
00:28:18.436 --> 00:28:22.465
So you can see that the space
that was added was between here,

514
00:28:22.465 --> 00:28:24.660
not between the lines.

515
00:28:24.660 --> 00:28:29.440
So that can be really handy if you're
formatting bullets with multiple lines.

516
00:28:29.440 --> 00:28:33.038
And I really like to point that out
because I use a lot of space after

517
00:28:33.038 --> 00:28:33.835
paragraphs.

518
00:28:33.835 --> 00:28:37.891
And the one last thing I wanted
to throw in there before we close

519
00:28:37.891 --> 00:28:42.416
this formatting section,
is formatting within the speaker notes.

520
00:28:42.416 --> 00:28:47.324
And I have, let's go ahead and open up
the speaker notes, and you can see if I

521
00:28:47.324 --> 00:28:51.564
pull this up, I have a decent amount
of text in the speaker notes.

522
00:28:51.564 --> 00:28:56.684
And if I take this in the normal view and
start using the bold, okay, that works.

523
00:28:56.684 --> 00:29:00.670
And I apply it to be red,
that didn't work okay.

524
00:29:00.670 --> 00:29:03.400
So maybe I'll make it red and
I'll make it 48 points.

525
00:29:04.420 --> 00:29:05.830
I guess it just doesn't work, right?

526
00:29:06.840 --> 00:29:11.291
Kind of, you can do your basic
formatting of the bullets and

527
00:29:11.291 --> 00:29:15.040
bold and
things like that within the normal view.

528
00:29:15.040 --> 00:29:19.603
But that red and that font size,
it's there you just don't see it.

529
00:29:19.603 --> 00:29:22.377
We're gonna go over to what's
known as the Notes view, okay?

530
00:29:22.377 --> 00:29:26.858
If I go to my View tab on the ribbon and
I go to my Notes page, it did take.

531
00:29:26.858 --> 00:29:29.274
[LAUGH] I have big red text there.

532
00:29:29.274 --> 00:29:32.665
So it's just really demonstrating
to you that any formatting,

533
00:29:32.665 --> 00:29:35.150
you can format your speaker notes.

534
00:29:35.150 --> 00:29:38.100
You just don't see it unless
you're in the notes page view.

535
00:29:38.100 --> 00:29:39.100
And this could be really good.

536
00:29:39.100 --> 00:29:41.820
If I was using this in a presentation,

537
00:29:41.820 --> 00:29:46.860
I cannot forget to talk about
formatting text and speaker notes.

538
00:29:46.860 --> 00:29:49.804
You can make it big and
boulder or different font for

539
00:29:49.804 --> 00:29:52.352
you as a speaker to be able to look at and
see.

540
00:29:52.352 --> 00:29:54.884
And you can do a lot more, oops sorry.

541
00:29:54.884 --> 00:29:57.760
[LAUGH] I got the wrong mouse cursor icon.

542
00:29:57.760 --> 00:30:02.693
I could come in here and start doing
different types of formating here.

543
00:30:02.693 --> 00:30:07.721
So I can use it for myself, but
you gotta go into the notes page view and

544
00:30:07.721 --> 00:30:11.300
I just wanted to point that
out that it does work.

545
00:30:11.300 --> 00:30:14.072
You can't format your
slides in the notes view,

546
00:30:14.072 --> 00:30:16.313
but you can format your speaker notes.

547
00:30:16.313 --> 00:30:17.651
>> All right Vonne, well,

548
00:30:17.651 --> 00:30:21.932
that's a lot of information right there
to think about in terms of formatting.

549
00:30:21.932 --> 00:30:26.370
Formatting is a very important part of
creating a PowerPoint presentation.

550
00:30:26.370 --> 00:30:28.962
Because that's what really makes
the impact that you wanna make.

551
00:30:28.962 --> 00:30:32.150
You wanna be able to differentiate
between let's say like a title, and

552
00:30:32.150 --> 00:30:34.610
then of course the text
that we have inside.

553
00:30:34.610 --> 00:30:38.020
And so you may wanna make sure that you
take advantage of some of the different

554
00:30:38.020 --> 00:30:42.510
techniques, to be able to do the character
spacing as well as the paragraph spacing,

555
00:30:42.510 --> 00:30:45.740
just like Vonne showed us and
also some of those effency techniques.

556
00:30:45.740 --> 00:30:47.480
Like using the format painter.

557
00:30:47.480 --> 00:30:49.930
These are all good techniques for
us to think about.

558
00:30:49.930 --> 00:30:53.426
And that you give presentations of course
take a look at all of your speaker notes

559
00:30:53.426 --> 00:30:55.787
and see some of the other
things that you can do there.

560
00:30:55.787 --> 00:31:00.384
But this is also a great place for
us to sign off for ITProTV.

561
00:31:00.384 --> 00:31:01.929
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

562
00:31:01.929 --> 00:31:02.788
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

563
00:31:02.788 --> 00:31:07.165
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft PowerPoint 2016 shows.

564
00:31:07.165 --> 00:31:13.376
[MUSIC]

565
00:31:13.376 --> 00:31:16.231
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne demonstrate how to use images in PowerPoint.   They show how to insert an image and how to manipulate the image by using the sizing handles and different tools that can change the appearance of the image on a slide.   They discuss the importance of image size and cropping too.  Lastly, Vonne also demonstrates how to remove some background from some images.
episodes.title: Images
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.265
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.265 --> 00:00:02.795
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.795 --> 00:00:08.226
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:08.226 --> 00:00:12.101
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.101 --> 00:00:15.096
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.096 --> 00:00:20.270
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today you're
watching Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

7
00:00:20.270 --> 00:00:24.660
We're specifically gonna be diving into
the realm of images inside of PowerPoint

8
00:00:24.660 --> 00:00:25.330
2016.

9
00:00:25.330 --> 00:00:26.610
And here to help us is, of course,

10
00:00:26.610 --> 00:00:29.280
our PowerPoint expert herself,
Miss Vonne Smith.

11
00:00:29.280 --> 00:00:30.860
Vonne, welcome back to the studios.

12
00:00:30.860 --> 00:00:33.818
And let's talk about the idea
of working with images today,

13
00:00:33.818 --> 00:00:35.217
what are we taking a look at?

14
00:00:35.217 --> 00:00:36.905
>> We are going to be
taking a look at the cats.

15
00:00:36.905 --> 00:00:37.883
[LAUGH]
>> Cats?

16
00:00:37.883 --> 00:00:39.163
>> Cats, cats, cats, so

17
00:00:39.163 --> 00:00:42.955
we're gonna use the same thing we've
been going along with our cats.

18
00:00:42.955 --> 00:00:46.161
And we're going to be
inserting pictures of my cats-

19
00:00:46.161 --> 00:00:46.850
>> Cats.

20
00:00:46.850 --> 00:00:50.390
>> Into our PowerPoint presentation as
well as going to find images online.

21
00:00:50.390 --> 00:00:55.040
So if we're gonna be working with images,
you're gonna have to have an image.

22
00:00:55.040 --> 00:00:56.555
So those are your different options.

23
00:00:56.555 --> 00:00:59.945
If you have a file or does the internet
have a file for you to get?

24
00:00:59.945 --> 00:01:04.658
So I have a PowerPoint presentation
created to kind of help us along.

25
00:01:04.658 --> 00:01:11.650
I have Images.pptx, and
we've got our images, okay?

26
00:01:11.650 --> 00:01:16.940
I want to start with a blank side, so we
can just go ahead and insert the images.

27
00:01:16.940 --> 00:01:21.700
And, well, I think that's the easiest
way to start, is go to the Insert tab.

28
00:01:21.700 --> 00:01:22.990
And you go to Pictures.

29
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:25.180
I've been saying Images,
but it does say Pictures.

30
00:01:25.180 --> 00:01:28.720
All right, now these are the ones
that I have on my computer, so

31
00:01:28.720 --> 00:01:30.320
I'm going to go ahead and click on here.

32
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:33.960
Now I do have a whole
folder full of images.

33
00:01:33.960 --> 00:01:38.020
They are on my Desktop, so I'll just say,
therefore I know they're on the Desktop.

34
00:01:38.020 --> 00:01:38.985
I know they're in the images.

35
00:01:38.985 --> 00:01:42.004
And so
you can see all the different pictures.

36
00:01:42.004 --> 00:01:43.502
>> Right?
>> Of cats.

37
00:01:43.502 --> 00:01:44.830
>> Lots of cats.

38
00:01:44.830 --> 00:01:46.184
But I have some scenery in there as well.

39
00:01:46.184 --> 00:01:46.983
>> Yes, okay.

40
00:01:46.983 --> 00:01:48.587
>> Got some nice sunsets and everything.

41
00:01:48.587 --> 00:01:49.287
>> With cats.

42
00:01:49.287 --> 00:01:54.775
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so
why don't we pick that one?

43
00:01:54.775 --> 00:01:58.443
Why don't we go ahead pick this,
Fuego looking all regal.

44
00:01:58.443 --> 00:02:00.405
>> With the sunset in the background,
how nice.

45
00:02:00.405 --> 00:02:03.250
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

46
00:02:03.250 --> 00:02:07.430
All right, the design ideas keeps popping
up cuz it really wants to help me.

47
00:02:07.430 --> 00:02:11.320
I'm not ready to tell you exactly what
that is even though it's really cool.

48
00:02:12.440 --> 00:02:14.250
>> So we're just gonna go ahead and
get the image in.

49
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:18.880
And there is Fuego looking like
the lion that he thinks he is.

50
00:02:18.880 --> 00:02:22.340
So, and that's it really,
I mean we could stop right there.

51
00:02:22.340 --> 00:02:24.470
>> All right.
>> But obviously there's a lot more to do.

52
00:02:24.470 --> 00:02:26.602
>> Okay.
>> With working with our pictures.

53
00:02:26.602 --> 00:02:29.797
For example, well first thing
is he's kind of big, right.

54
00:02:29.797 --> 00:02:32.595
He's taking up the whole slide and
I don't want him to be that big.

55
00:02:32.595 --> 00:02:35.642
So you have how you can resize and
rotate and

56
00:02:35.642 --> 00:02:40.136
your pictures if I click it once
cuz I got that four point arrow.

57
00:02:40.136 --> 00:02:43.252
Because that means that I'm over
an object that I can select.

58
00:02:43.252 --> 00:02:48.776
I go ahead and get the resizing handles or
the little dots on the corners.

59
00:02:48.776 --> 00:02:52.398
If you hover those you get
a two pointed arrow now.

60
00:02:52.398 --> 00:02:55.950
You wanna go from a corner when
you're resizing a picture.

61
00:02:55.950 --> 00:02:57.530
Because if you go from a side.

62
00:02:57.530 --> 00:03:03.385
You see then it's like, I mean, Fuego
thinks he's smaller than he really is.

63
00:03:03.385 --> 00:03:08.332
But now it distorts the image or
aspect ratio of the picture is off, so

64
00:03:08.332 --> 00:03:10.820
I'm gonna go ahead and undo that.

65
00:03:10.820 --> 00:03:13.717
But, if you grab a corner,
and you click hold and drag.

66
00:03:13.717 --> 00:03:16.229
Do you see how,
if you do the corner, it's.

67
00:03:16.229 --> 00:03:19.501
I'm gonna keep the width and
height proportionate to itself.

68
00:03:19.501 --> 00:03:24.761
And that's what you really would
like to do, at least, that I think,

69
00:03:24.761 --> 00:03:30.230
cuz I've seen presentations, or
anything with a skewed image.

70
00:03:30.230 --> 00:03:33.532
I see it right away, but
that's because again I'm in design work.

71
00:03:33.532 --> 00:03:36.560
And so I notice it right away, other
people are like, what's wrong with it?

72
00:03:36.560 --> 00:03:37.640
I'm like, no.

73
00:03:37.640 --> 00:03:39.945
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So keep that corner and

00:22:03.110 --> 00:22:07.120
JPEG is like for photographs that

00:22:08.890 --> 00:22:11.960

00:22:20.055 --> 00:22:25.400
GIFs is where you have less color support,

00:22:26.440 --> 00:22:30.110

00:22:30.110 --> 00:22:32.940

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne take a look at using formatting and themes to help make our presentations visually appealing.  Vonne demonstrates how to apply a theme and modify a theme too.  She also demonstrates different elements that can be changed to create our own theme if we choose.  She uses a background color with a theme to show how we can create a custom theme that can be saved and used again later.  Lastly, she shows a new feature, with office 365,  the design ideas that helps you to get started with PointPoint appeal.
episodes.title: Formatting Slides and Themes

678
00:37:27.872 --> 00:37:31.620
especially if you can't find everything
else in a preset that you want.

679
00:37:31.620 --> 00:37:35.141
Adding in some shades, being able to
manipulate them, change their color,

680
00:37:35.141 --> 00:37:38.825
being able to add text to them is really a
valuable tool that we can really make sure

681
00:37:38.825 --> 00:37:41.659
that you have the customization
that you really want to have.

682
00:37:41.659 --> 00:37:45.400
So that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

683
00:37:45.400 --> 00:37:48.383
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

684
00:37:48.383 --> 00:37:49.190
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

685
00:37:49.190 --> 00:37:53.256
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

686
00:37:53.256 --> 00:37:59.992
[MUSIC]

687
00:37:59.992 --> 00:38:02.410
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne take a look at using Smart Art in PowerPoint.  Smart Art is a combination of shapes and text and formatting that help to convey the relationship of data we want to present, according to the duo.  They demonstrate how easy it is use it and add them to our presentation.  Vonne demonstrates how to add shapes, delete and modify shapes to make our point.  She demonstrates the use of lists and the hierarchy within the Smart Art to Convey topics as well as organizational order.
episodes.title: SmartArt
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.494
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet-

2
00:00:02.494 --> 00:00:08.227
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.227 --> 00:00:12.003
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.003 --> 00:00:15.440
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.440 --> 00:00:20.700
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today,
you're watching Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

6
00:00:20.700 --> 00:00:24.080
We're specifically gonna be diving
into the realm of smart art.

7
00:00:24.080 --> 00:00:26.110
And here to help us
understand what it is and

8
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:28.955
why we tend to use it,
is gonna be Miss Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:28.955 --> 00:00:30.570
Vonne, welcome back to the show.

10
00:00:30.570 --> 00:00:32.836
So let's begin with that
particular question.

11
00:00:32.836 --> 00:00:36.310
What is it and
why would we choose to use smart art?

12
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:38.440
>> Perfect introduction, exactly.

13
00:00:38.440 --> 00:00:40.280
So smart art, what is it?

14
00:00:40.280 --> 00:00:41.887
It's art that's smart.

15
00:00:41.887 --> 00:00:42.416
>> Thank you.

16
00:00:42.416 --> 00:00:45.840
>> And we're done.
[LAUGH] No it's really just another way

17
00:00:45.840 --> 00:00:50.035
that we can graphically
represent art information.

18
00:00:50.035 --> 00:00:54.281
Because we've been using slides where
we just add some text in there and

19
00:00:54.281 --> 00:00:56.917
make a list and
bullet points to talk about.

20
00:00:56.917 --> 00:01:01.327
But you could if you wanted to,
what if it was an easy way for

21
00:01:01.327 --> 00:01:03.937
you to be able to put those points or

22
00:01:03.937 --> 00:01:08.440
information into some type
of graphic graph-like thing?

23
00:01:08.440 --> 00:01:09.744
[LAUGH]
>> Representation?

24
00:01:09.744 --> 00:01:13.930
>> Yeah, certainly, a great,
great explanation here Vonne.

25
00:01:13.930 --> 00:01:17.550
It's really honestly,
easiest to show you what it looks like.

26
00:01:17.550 --> 00:01:22.210
So we can get an idea pf what
exactly smart art can do for us.

27
00:01:22.210 --> 00:01:23.674
So we're gonna go through
a couple examples.

28
00:01:23.674 --> 00:01:25.968
So why don't we go ahead and
just dive right in?

29
00:01:25.968 --> 00:01:29.985
I haven't even started PowerPoint
because I wanted to do this episode with

30
00:01:29.985 --> 00:01:30.630
a new file.

31
00:01:30.630 --> 00:01:34.029
We're just gonna start from scratch and
just kind of throw the smart art in there.

32
00:01:34.029 --> 00:01:36.420
We're gonna put some information in it and
see what we can do.

33
00:01:36.420 --> 00:01:39.422
So let's go ahead and start PowerPoint,

34
00:01:39.422 --> 00:01:42.781
I'm gonna use my search bar,
get us started.

35
00:01:42.781 --> 00:01:44.807
And I don't know why I'm
not full screened yet.

36
00:01:44.807 --> 00:01:46.014
But I can go ahead and

37
00:01:46.014 --> 00:01:50.067
full screen by clicking our maximize
button to go ahead and do that.

38
00:01:50.067 --> 00:01:53.508
All right, so why don't we go ahead and
start with a blank presentation?

39
00:01:53.508 --> 00:01:55.600
Cuz that's where we're gonna go.

40
00:01:55.600 --> 00:02:00.650
And just to have fun we're just gonna add
our little SmartArt with a capital A.

41
00:02:00.650 --> 00:02:04.622
And we can add our subtitle to go along.

42
00:02:04.622 --> 00:02:06.662
And whoops, how about we do that?

43
00:02:06.662 --> 00:02:09.680
All right, perfect, so
we've got our title slide.

44
00:02:09.680 --> 00:02:13.240
We're gonna add a new slide
with our title and content.

45
00:02:13.240 --> 00:02:16.170
And we've been doing this
throughout the entire show and

46
00:02:16.170 --> 00:02:19.080
we've been using all of these
little buttons along the way.

47
00:02:19.080 --> 00:02:22.070
Well, actually we haven't been using the
buttons to much because we haven't done

48
00:02:22.070 --> 00:02:23.832
the Tables and the Charts,
which we'll get to.

49
00:02:23.832 --> 00:02:26.910
But we did do the pictures,
that was one of them.

50
00:02:26.910 --> 00:02:31.808
But one of the other buttons that we
have here in out content placeholder is

51
00:02:31.808 --> 00:02:34.577
our option to insert a smart art graphic.

52
00:02:34.577 --> 00:02:38.050
So that's a good place
of any to put this in.

53
00:02:38.050 --> 00:02:39.260
So we're gonna go ahead and click on it.

54
00:02:39.260 --> 00:02:44.048
And then it goes ahead and
brings us into Smart Art Graphic Library.

55
00:02:44.048 --> 00:02:46.701
Where I have all these different ways and

56
00:02:46.701 --> 00:02:51.160
examples of how we want to organize
the content of our information.

57
00:02:51.160 --> 00:02:55.406
So if we were going to be talking
about cats, dogs, and horses,

58
00:02:55.406 --> 00:02:59.274
and those were our main talking
points within this slide.

59
00:02:59.274 --> 00:03:04.900
Well, why don't I go ahead and look at
the different options that PowerPoint has

60
00:03:04.900 --> 00:03:10.048
to insert a list in pictures, or
in graphical elements, how about that?

61
00:03:10.048 --> 00:03:13.981
So you can see that I can put them in
hexagons, ooh, that looks fancy, or

62
00:03:13.981 --> 00:03:16.240
I can do them in just certain boxes.

63
00:03:16.240 --> 00:03:17.652
You have different ways,

64
00:03:17.652 --> 00:03:20.934
think about if you had different
topics that had subtopics.

65
00:03:20.934 --> 00:03:25.200
This could be a nice way to
represent that information in

66
00:03:25.200 --> 00:03:30.450
a somewhat graphical format, so
it's not just text on a slide.

67
00:03:30.450 --> 00:03:32.990
You can add a little pizzazz,
we'll call it Ronnie.

68
00:03:32.990 --> 00:03:36.020
We can pizzazz it all
up with our different

69
00:03:36.020 --> 00:03:37.620
ways that we can represent lists.

70
00:03:37.620 --> 00:03:42.540
And you can see over on the left hand
side that you have different categories

71
00:03:42.540 --> 00:03:46.040
of what you are wanting
to put on the slide.

72
00:03:46.040 --> 00:03:51.650
Maybe we are talking about the process of
what we do when we get up in the morning.

73
00:03:51.650 --> 00:03:55.170
We get up, we brush our teeth,
we drink our coffee.

74
00:03:55.170 --> 00:03:59.000
That could be something that we could
represent with arrows along the way.

75
00:03:59.000 --> 00:04:00.915
Here, let me go ahead and
get to that so you could see.

76
00:04:00.915 --> 00:04:03.153
So you could see if I
click on some of these,

77
00:04:03.153 --> 00:04:06.725
it's going to give me a nice preview
over on that right-hand side.

78
00:04:06.725 --> 00:04:11.517
So that's a nice way that we can represent
a step by step process that we're

79
00:04:11.517 --> 00:04:13.127
trying to present here.

80
00:04:13.127 --> 00:04:17.786
And you can go on down through
the different categories like a cycle, or

81
00:04:17.786 --> 00:04:21.836
a hierarchy if we were doing
an organizational chart matrix.

82
00:04:21.836 --> 00:04:27.370
Different ways we can represent how
things interact with each other,

83
00:04:27.370 --> 00:04:30.476
and the relationships that they have.

84
00:04:30.476 --> 00:04:34.134
Okay, so we've got all of these
different types of smart art,

85
00:04:34.134 --> 00:04:35.806
so let's start with a list.

86
00:04:35.806 --> 00:04:39.222
And we're gonna just start with the very
first one, just go super basic,

87
00:04:39.222 --> 00:04:40.389
with a basic block list.

88
00:04:40.389 --> 00:04:46.930
Okay perfect, go ahead and click OK,
and it inserts this smart art graphic.

89
00:04:46.930 --> 00:04:51.390
So you can see that it starts off with
these five boxes that we could then

90
00:04:51.390 --> 00:04:52.380
add text into it.

91
00:04:52.380 --> 00:04:55.320
And that is what this little text
in the little brackets says,

92
00:04:55.320 --> 00:04:57.775
given its indication that we can add text.

93
00:04:57.775 --> 00:05:02.450
Just kind of like how we have our
placeholders and like the double tap to

94
00:05:02.450 --> 00:05:06.670
add titles, trying to just give us
a little bit of a hint of what we can do.

95
00:05:06.670 --> 00:05:10.050
So with this selected, or
you can click your cursor in it,

96
00:05:10.050 --> 00:05:11.940
whichever way you want to go.

97
00:05:11.940 --> 00:05:13.990
Either way,
it would still go ahead and add text.

98
00:05:13.990 --> 00:05:19.041
Just like we had added text and shapes in
our shapes episode, these are just shapes.

99
00:05:19.041 --> 00:05:24.240
All right, so we're gonna just type in
cats, because that's what I said earlier.

100
00:05:24.240 --> 00:05:28.070
And if I wanna add text to this other one,
you click and you can add Dogs.

101
00:05:28.070 --> 00:05:33.022
Now notice I'm adding in words that
are pretty small, or just a few letters.

102
00:05:33.022 --> 00:05:37.952
So it's automatically sizing
the text in those objects to

103
00:05:37.952 --> 00:05:43.300
accommodate whatever size,
text, or words that I have.

104
00:05:43.300 --> 00:05:50.190
So if I came over here to this third
one and said, This is more text

105
00:05:50.190 --> 00:05:55.555
in this shape, but you can see, I'm trying
to type and talk and it's not working.

106
00:05:55.555 --> 00:05:57.160
Yes, there we go.

107
00:05:57.160 --> 00:05:58.220
I'm just gonna [LAUGH] go with that one.

108
00:05:58.220 --> 00:06:02.549
So you can that it's automatically
resizing this text as I type in the box.

109
00:06:02.549 --> 00:06:07.271
But the nice thing is,
to stay consistent in the other shapes,

110
00:06:07.271 --> 00:06:12.260
the cats and the dogs,
are automatically gonna autosize as well,

111
00:06:12.260 --> 00:06:15.668
which I like,
because I do like uniformity.

112
00:06:15.668 --> 00:06:20.420
So I think that's a nice way to
kinda help us along, and resize or

113
00:06:20.420 --> 00:06:25.460
auto-fit the text to whatever box
has the largest amount of text.

114
00:06:25.460 --> 00:06:29.653
And so it will go ahead and
accommodate all of the objects, and so

115
00:06:29.653 --> 00:06:31.525
you can keep on adding text.

116
00:06:31.525 --> 00:06:39.213
But what if I only want to talk
about Cats, Dogs, and Horses?

117
00:06:39.213 --> 00:06:43.855
It's all I have, well, I have three,
all right sorry, that will be two,

118
00:06:43.855 --> 00:06:48.304
[LAUGH] two other boxes in a smaller
graphic that I'm not wanting to use.

119
00:06:48.304 --> 00:06:51.760
All you gotta do is just delete it, okay?

120
00:06:51.760 --> 00:06:53.746
You can click,
now if you have your cursor,

121
00:06:53.746 --> 00:06:56.497
if you have a flashing cursor in that and
I hit the Delete key.

122
00:06:56.497 --> 00:07:01.401
You could see that nothing's gonna happen
right now, because it's thinking that you

123
00:07:01.401 --> 00:07:04.780
want to delete text in that text box,
or that shape.

124
00:07:04.780 --> 00:07:08.010
That's not what I wanna do,
I wanna eliminate the entire shape.

125
00:07:08.010 --> 00:07:10.020
So what you have to do
is select to effect,

126
00:07:10.020 --> 00:07:13.390
you have to select what
you want to get rid of.

127
00:07:13.390 --> 00:07:19.000
So I need to get to that four pointed
arrow on the edge to get the whole shape,

128
00:07:19.000 --> 00:07:22.210
not the text in the box.

129
00:07:22.210 --> 00:07:25.480
So when I have that, now you can hit
the Delete key on your keyboard.

130
00:07:25.480 --> 00:07:29.970
And it will go away, or the Backspace key,
depending on which one you have.

131
00:07:29.970 --> 00:07:33.740
So you can go ahead, and I don't want
that one, so I can ahead and delete that.

132
00:07:33.740 --> 00:07:37.775
And now I have my three shapes
that I wanna talk about.

133
00:07:37.775 --> 00:07:43.430
So a different way that I can represent
topics that I wanna talk about

134
00:07:43.430 --> 00:07:48.790
in a graphical format rather than
just plain text on the page.

135
00:07:48.790 --> 00:07:51.017
I guess this would be a slide,
not the page, Ronnie, so-

136
00:07:51.017 --> 00:07:51.802
>> All right,

137
00:07:51.802 --> 00:07:56.680
Vonne, taking the idea here where we
can remove those different shapes.

138
00:07:56.680 --> 00:07:59.329
That's a really good thing if I
actually need to to have less.

139
00:07:59.329 --> 00:08:04.280
But since I started off with five,
let's say is that the maximum that I have,

140
00:08:04.280 --> 00:08:06.942
though, in the shape,
or can I add a six or

141
00:08:06.942 --> 00:08:11.840
seventh box to add in something like
bunnies and elephants if I wanted to?

142
00:08:11.840 --> 00:08:15.180
>> Well, Ronnie, you know I'm always
willing to add bunnies into the mix

143
00:08:15.180 --> 00:08:18.790
when we're talking about any type
of animal, so that's a great point.

144
00:08:18.790 --> 00:08:22.365
What if I wanted to add a shape?

145
00:08:22.365 --> 00:08:25.070
I told you how to delete one,
but how do I add one in?

146
00:08:25.070 --> 00:08:28.160
And whether that be that I started
with three and now I need four, or

147
00:08:28.160 --> 00:08:31.150
I started with five and now I need six or
seven, let's add some shapes.

148
00:08:31.150 --> 00:08:32.128
So let's get back in here.

149
00:08:32.128 --> 00:08:35.717
You can see that I'm on the Horses object,
so

150
00:08:35.717 --> 00:08:41.960
that makes a difference to when you adding
a shape, does it go before or after?

151
00:08:41.960 --> 00:08:45.960
So always make sure that you know
where you're at before you go.

152
00:08:45.960 --> 00:08:50.165
So on this contextual tab, this designed
tab that is part of the SmartArt tools

153
00:08:50.165 --> 00:08:55.000
that has come up because I have added this
particular element and I have it selected.

154
00:08:55.000 --> 00:08:59.688
Over here on the left you have Add Shape,
and I can just click it right now and

155
00:08:59.688 --> 00:09:03.052
it would just do the default
option of adding a shape.

156
00:09:03.052 --> 00:09:06.860
But you do have some other options
that you have in the drop down.

157
00:09:06.860 --> 00:09:11.089
You can see that do I want to add a shape
after, or do I wanna add a shape before?

158
00:09:11.089 --> 00:09:14.428
Again, depending on where I'm at, whether
you want it in the front or the back.

159
00:09:14.428 --> 00:09:17.751
You can see I do have some other
options that are grayed out,

160
00:09:17.751 --> 00:09:21.740
the reason those are grayed out is
because I'm not in a SmartArt graphic

161
00:09:21.740 --> 00:09:23.820
that allows for above and below.

162
00:09:23.820 --> 00:09:25.770
If you were in some type of hierarchy,

163
00:09:25.770 --> 00:09:29.190
then that would be where
you could go up or down.

164
00:09:29.190 --> 00:09:31.790
So I'm gonna go ahead and
add a shape after.

165
00:09:31.790 --> 00:09:34.210
I click on after and then it adds a shape.

166
00:09:34.210 --> 00:09:38.358
And so I can go ahead and
type in bunnies and there we go.

167
00:09:38.358 --> 00:09:44.460
And I've got all four topics that I want
to include on this particular slide.

168
00:09:44.460 --> 00:09:47.205
But you can see that
it's very blue right now.

169
00:09:47.205 --> 00:09:51.766
Well one, because we don't have
any theme that we have applied.

170
00:09:51.766 --> 00:09:56.709
We just have the Office theme, so that's
always the basic kind of stark background,

171
00:09:56.709 --> 00:09:57.749
if you wanna say.

172
00:09:58.770 --> 00:10:02.920
But we'll get to design things in just
second because I can go ahead and

173
00:10:02.920 --> 00:10:08.340
change the colors of this based
on whatever theme I'm working on.

174
00:10:08.340 --> 00:10:11.590
And I can go into the colorful or
maybe a monochromatic look, and

175
00:10:11.590 --> 00:10:14.870
I have these different
options of how it's going to

176
00:10:14.870 --> 00:10:18.670
apply the colors to these different
shapes within the SmartArt.

177
00:10:18.670 --> 00:10:21.450
I always like to go for
the colorful option.

178
00:10:21.450 --> 00:10:25.130
And then you have over here on the,
beside the change colors,

179
00:10:25.130 --> 00:10:27.150
you have your options for
different styles.

180
00:10:27.150 --> 00:10:32.700
Now this is where I, instead of formatting
every single individual shape like you can

181
00:10:32.700 --> 00:10:36.070
when you're inserting a shape or inserting
a picture, it treats it all as one.

182
00:10:36.070 --> 00:10:41.003
And it gives me some nice quick and easy
ways of making this look a little fancier

183
00:10:41.003 --> 00:10:45.960
using bevel and emboss and shadows, and
we could even go into some 3D-ness.

184
00:10:45.960 --> 00:10:46.898
And like okay well,

185
00:10:46.898 --> 00:10:50.870
that might be, well that would be cute
if we were talking about a keyboard.

186
00:10:50.870 --> 00:10:53.960
But you can see different
options that I have for

187
00:10:53.960 --> 00:10:59.860
quickly making this SmartArt graphic look
just a little fancier, little more fun.

188
00:10:59.860 --> 00:11:03.010
So maybe I'll go with
that option right there.

189
00:11:04.010 --> 00:11:06.370
Now I am in a list SmartArt graphic,

190
00:11:06.370 --> 00:11:11.029
what if I wanted to change it back to
those hexagons that I saw earlier?

191
00:11:11.029 --> 00:11:15.884
Well you can see in the layouts it gives
me all the different ways that lists

192
00:11:15.884 --> 00:11:17.618
can be shown in SmartArt.

193
00:11:17.618 --> 00:11:21.011
So maybe I could go ahead and
put those hexagons in there.

194
00:11:21.011 --> 00:11:25.905
[SOUND] That's a little small, or
I could go into maybe have it stacked.

195
00:11:25.905 --> 00:11:30.902
But I think you get the idea here is that
I can go ahead and quickly change all

196
00:11:30.902 --> 00:11:35.740
of that content into easy ways of
showing different representations,

197
00:11:35.740 --> 00:11:40.520
graphical representations,
of lists and it's pretty handy dandy.

198
00:11:40.520 --> 00:11:43.330
I'm gonna go back to the beginning and
there we go.

199
00:11:43.330 --> 00:11:45.590
Got some nice little
SmartArt to start with.

200
00:11:45.590 --> 00:11:48.540
>> All right, Vaughn, I see that every
time you even change the different shapes,

201
00:11:48.540 --> 00:11:51.270
and that you put everything on
there that you wanted to do,

202
00:11:51.270 --> 00:11:53.440
it changed everything but
the order of those shapes.

203
00:11:53.440 --> 00:11:56.000
Is there somewhere we can
actually move those around and

204
00:11:56.000 --> 00:11:58.080
put them into another
order if we needed to?

205
00:11:58.080 --> 00:11:59.250
>> Yes there is.

206
00:11:59.250 --> 00:12:01.090
And so let's go ahead and jump in there.

207
00:12:01.090 --> 00:12:06.370

the shapes hang off of that top level?

427
00:24:38.350 --> 00:24:40.470
And they're both going to the right.

428
00:24:40.470 --> 00:24:43.240
Which, it's not that big of a deal,
but to me I don't know.

429
00:24:43.240 --> 00:24:46.600
For some reason I really wanna
see the lines on the other side.

430
00:24:46.600 --> 00:24:49.550
Now you have to think of
where they're hanging off of.

431
00:24:49.550 --> 00:24:55.240
So if I go back up to Denise,
up here on my ribbon, on the layout,

432
00:24:55.240 --> 00:25:01.310
you could see that I have the different
ways of left hanging, or right hanging.

433
00:25:01.310 --> 00:25:03.790
It's more of a design thing for me.

434
00:25:03.790 --> 00:25:06.360
I like to see it that way.

435
00:25:06.360 --> 00:25:11.820
So it kind of go off to the side and
I can change the layout

436
00:25:11.820 --> 00:25:18.120
of how the subordinates I'm gonna say are
underneath in this organizational chart.

437
00:25:18.120 --> 00:25:20.300
I'm gonna go ahead back from my zoom.

438
00:25:20.300 --> 00:25:22.452
And that's how you can add an org chart.

439
00:25:22.452 --> 00:25:26.466
You can take If I wanted
to make this shape bigger,

440
00:25:26.466 --> 00:25:30.206
I could make each shape
individually bigger.

441
00:25:30.206 --> 00:25:34.208
Or I could make the entire SmartArt
graphic bigger, just like we had done with

442
00:25:34.208 --> 00:25:38.790
any of other other episodes when we were
doing the shapes, they're all shapes.

443
00:25:38.790 --> 00:25:39.670
This is an object.

444
00:25:39.670 --> 00:25:43.278
So you can still do all the same things
that you could do with formatting

445
00:25:43.278 --> 00:25:44.760
your object individually.

446
00:25:44.760 --> 00:25:49.569
For example, if you wanted to take this
text and make it a different font,

447
00:25:49.569 --> 00:25:51.740
you can go ahead and do that.

448
00:25:51.740 --> 00:25:56.140
I didn't want you to think that
you only had these options,

449
00:25:56.140 --> 00:25:59.800
when using your smarter graphic,
they're just shapes.

450
00:25:59.800 --> 00:26:03.161
So you can pick out any piece,
do anything you want.

451
00:26:03.161 --> 00:26:07.837
You see, I wanna actually don't think
we've been gone to the format tab because

452
00:26:07.837 --> 00:26:12.444
to me all the kind of preset designs and
formats that SmartArt graphics give me,

453
00:26:12.444 --> 00:26:13.330
I like them.

454
00:26:13.330 --> 00:26:18.190
So I usually don't go much further
than what the defaults give me.

455
00:26:18.190 --> 00:26:20.650
But just driving home that point of,

456
00:26:20.650 --> 00:26:23.360
you wanna put a drop shadow
on just this one piece?

457
00:26:23.360 --> 00:26:24.540
Go right ahead.

458
00:26:24.540 --> 00:26:28.620
Or maybe you want all of the texts
in this to have all word art.

459
00:26:28.620 --> 00:26:33.010
You can click out to the whole piece,
of the SmartArt graphic.

460
00:26:33.010 --> 00:26:36.840
Put on, that's kind of hard to read,
but you can put out word styles.

461
00:26:36.840 --> 00:26:42.880
So, just showing you, you can do
whatever you want with your SmartArt.

462
00:26:42.880 --> 00:26:46.360
I just tend to like to go with
the defaults cuz I think they look pretty.

463
00:26:47.718 --> 00:26:48.329
>> All right,

464
00:26:48.329 --> 00:26:52.930
Vonne, well that's a lot of great
information about the use of SmartArt.

465
00:26:52.930 --> 00:26:55.790
Remember that when we actually do use
SmartArt, we're normally using it for

466
00:26:55.790 --> 00:26:56.560
a purpose.

467
00:26:56.560 --> 00:26:59.070
We're really combining text
as well as shapes together

468
00:26:59.070 --> 00:27:02.330
to make sure that we get the information
across the way that we want to.

469
00:27:02.330 --> 00:27:04.453
And most of us,
when we first begin with PowerPoint,

470
00:27:04.453 --> 00:27:06.920
we're not thinking about
creating organizational charts.

471
00:27:06.920 --> 00:27:10.527
But here's an easy way to do so, without
us having to add in every single element,

472
00:27:10.527 --> 00:27:12.694
and actually puts it in
the order that we need to.

473
00:27:12.694 --> 00:27:16.209
Whether it's a process, or
whether it's an organizational chart,

474
00:27:16.209 --> 00:27:20.453
whether we're trying to show a cyclic type
of relationship, whatever it might be.

475
00:27:20.453 --> 00:27:24.201
It's certainly worth us taking the time to
build use, because it means that we don't

476
00:27:24.201 --> 00:27:26.647
have to actually pick out
every element that we need to,

477
00:27:26.647 --> 00:27:30.080
to get it ready to display,
inside of our PowerPoint presentation.

478
00:27:30.080 --> 00:27:33.563
Thank you again Vonne, for helping us
here, and thank you also for watching.

479
00:27:33.563 --> 00:27:35.624
But it's a great place for us to sign off.

480
00:27:35.624 --> 00:27:38.478
For ITProTV I've been
your host Ronnie Wong.

481
00:27:38.478 --> 00:27:39.376
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

482
00:27:39.376 --> 00:27:43.353
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

483
00:27:43.353 --> 00:27:49.403
[MUSIC]

484
00:27:49.403 --> 00:27:52.860
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne begin to insert in a table in PowerPoint.  Vonne demonstrates the different parts of a created table and show how they can be manipulated and formatted.  She then show how to create tables and add data as well as change the table, the rows, columns and cells along with formatting to make the table display the way we want for a presentation.
episodes.title: Tables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.817 --> 00:00:02.971
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.971 --> 00:00:07.204
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.204 --> 00:00:08.347
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.347 --> 00:00:11.759
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.759 --> 00:00:14.349
>> Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.349 --> 00:00:15.934
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:15.934 --> 00:00:19.489
And today,
you're watching Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

8
00:00:19.489 --> 00:00:23.306
We're specifically gonna be taking a look
at using tables inside of our PowerPoint

9
00:00:23.306 --> 00:00:24.130
presentations.

10
00:00:24.130 --> 00:00:27.445
And here to help us out is gonna be,
well, Ms. Vonne Smith.

11
00:00:27.445 --> 00:00:28.759
Vonne, welcome back to our show.

12
00:00:28.759 --> 00:00:29.357
>> Hello.

13
00:00:29.357 --> 00:00:30.027
>> How are you doing today?

14
00:00:30.027 --> 00:00:30.686
>> I'm good.

15
00:00:30.686 --> 00:00:31.869
I'm ready to table it up.

16
00:00:31.869 --> 00:00:33.673
[LAUGH]
>> All right, Vonne, so

17
00:00:33.673 --> 00:00:37.110
let's start with the obvious question
about the idea of using tables.

18
00:00:37.110 --> 00:00:40.030
When in the world would we normally
want to use tables inside of

19
00:00:40.030 --> 00:00:41.558
our PowerPoint presentation?

20
00:00:41.558 --> 00:00:45.852
>> Well, if you have a lot of information
that maybe you want to compare and

21
00:00:45.852 --> 00:00:46.640
contrast and

22
00:00:46.640 --> 00:00:51.310
you wanna show it in a different format
than just listing it as bullet points.

23
00:00:51.310 --> 00:00:53.540
Or maybe you have a whole paragraph,

24
00:00:53.540 --> 00:00:58.250
a whole section about one thing in
the section about another thing and

25
00:00:58.250 --> 00:01:01.930
it's not really kind of giving
the message that you want.

26
00:01:01.930 --> 00:01:05.120
You could always organize
the information in tables.

27
00:01:05.120 --> 00:01:09.420
And a table consists of rows and columns
and where they intersect is a cell.

28
00:01:09.420 --> 00:01:12.280
And you can go ahead and
put the content into that cell and

29
00:01:12.280 --> 00:01:14.410
be able to see it as one piece.

30
00:01:14.410 --> 00:01:18.010
The nice thing is you could also
move it around as one element.

31
00:01:18.010 --> 00:01:21.803
And it becomes its own, well, object
within your PowerPoint presentation.

32
00:01:21.803 --> 00:01:25.507
So we could go ahead and get into it.

33
00:01:25.507 --> 00:01:29.619
And I have a file that
I created to just label

34
00:01:29.619 --> 00:01:33.284
the parts of a already created table.

35
00:01:33.284 --> 00:01:34.473
So you can hear and

36
00:01:34.473 --> 00:01:39.320
see some of the vocabulary that is
associated with working with a table.

37
00:01:39.320 --> 00:01:43.560
And then we're gonna go ahead and
re-create the table that we have.

38
00:01:43.560 --> 00:01:48.965
So I have a file in my PowerPoint
folder called Parts of a Table.

39
00:01:48.965 --> 00:01:51.156
>> [LAUGH]
>> I almost forgot the name of the file.

40
00:01:51.156 --> 00:01:52.513
[LAUGH] What are we doing?

41
00:01:52.513 --> 00:01:53.022
We're doing a table.

42
00:01:53.022 --> 00:01:54.730
All right, so here we go.

43
00:01:55.730 --> 00:01:57.500
Parts of a Table.

44
00:01:57.500 --> 00:02:02.940
I tried to go with why are things labeled
in blue and why are some labeled in green?

45
00:02:02.940 --> 00:02:07.651
The reason I went with that is ones are
more formating versus actual vocabulary,

46
00:02:07.651 --> 00:02:10.851
if you wanna say,
about the different parts of a cell.

47
00:02:10.851 --> 00:02:13.706
So you could see that we have the rows,
okay?

48
00:02:13.706 --> 00:02:16.185
A row would be across.

49
00:02:16.185 --> 00:02:17.239
Oo, now I'm just crossing it out.

50
00:02:17.239 --> 00:02:19.316
[LAUGH And then you have our columns.

51
00:02:19.316 --> 00:02:21.836
So columns go up and down, rows go across.

52
00:02:21.836 --> 00:02:25.453
And so you can go ahead and
see that where a row and

53
00:02:25.453 --> 00:02:28.725
a column intersect, that would be a cell.

54
00:02:28.725 --> 00:02:31.910
So, each one of these things,
we can call them,

55
00:02:31.910 --> 00:02:35.192
they are cells that you
input the information in.

56
00:02:35.192 --> 00:02:36.157
Now, this particular table,
across the top,

57
00:02:36.157 --> 00:02:37.750
you notice how there aren't any divide
lines between these cells is because we

58
00:02:37.750 --> 00:02:39.051
actually took a group of cells and
we merged them into one cell.

59
00:02:39.051 --> 00:02:42.068
So a merged cell,

60
00:02:42.068 --> 00:02:47.901
we'll be taking a couple of them,

61
00:02:47.901 --> 00:02:52.125
either across or down and

62
00:02:52.125 --> 00:02:57.969
creating one large cell out of it.

63
00:02:57.969 --> 00:03:03.200
And this particular one here,
total row, why did I add this?

64
00:03:03.200 --> 00:03:07.642
Because this is where it looks like,
that's where you always put totals,

65
00:03:07.642 --> 00:03:09.050
it's not necessarily.

66
00:03:09.050 --> 00:03:12.215
I think the way they name it
can be a little misleading.

67
00:03:12.215 --> 00:03:15.587
But normally,
if you have numbers like this,

68
00:03:15.587 --> 00:03:18.793
you would maybe total
them up at the bottom.

69
00:03:18.793 --> 00:03:22.025
But it doesn't have to be totaled numbers.

70
00:03:22.025 --> 00:03:26.345
It's really just how PowerPoint,
I almost said Excel.

71
00:03:26.345 --> 00:03:26.872
>> Yeah.

72
00:03:26.872 --> 00:03:29.340
>> Because Excel,
you use tables Excel as well.

73
00:03:29.340 --> 00:03:34.293
But it's a way that PowerPoint
just formats that particular last

74
00:03:34.293 --> 00:03:37.544
row in the way that it's using the styles.

75
00:03:37.544 --> 00:03:42.413
Cuz we've been doing a lot of things with
styles throughout our different episodes,

76
00:03:42.413 --> 00:03:46.876
with our smart art graphics and our shapes
and our pictures So if you say, yes,

77
00:03:46.876 --> 00:03:50.795
I want to format this last row as
a total row when you apply the styles,

78
00:03:50.795 --> 00:03:53.735
it will go ahead and
do that different formatting.

79
00:03:53.735 --> 00:03:58.683
Because I did apply this
style to this table,

80
00:03:58.683 --> 00:04:03.120
that went ahead and did the banded rows.

81
00:04:03.120 --> 00:04:07.202
You can see that each row has a different
color, like dark, light, dark, light.

82
00:04:07.202 --> 00:04:10.679
Why would you want to do that?

83
00:04:10.679 --> 00:04:11.879
It's cuz it's a little easier to read,

84
00:04:11.879 --> 00:04:13.234
especially if you have
a lot of information.

85
00:04:13.234 --> 00:04:16.582
Now in a PowerPoint,
you don't wanna get bigger than the slide.

86
00:04:16.582 --> 00:04:21.562
But if I had ten or twelve rows in here,
it's easier to differentiate if

87
00:04:21.562 --> 00:04:26.780
you have just a little bit of color
differentiation in between your rows.

88
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:33.750
So that's an example of banded rows
with this particular style that I chose.

89
00:04:33.750 --> 00:04:37.880
And then you also have how wide
each one of these columns and

90
00:04:37.880 --> 00:04:42.240
how wide, actually the other way, when
talking about rows, that would be heights.

91
00:04:42.240 --> 00:04:46.204
So widths and heights of
the different pieces of our table.

92
00:04:46.204 --> 00:04:48.061
And you can change them.

93
00:04:48.061 --> 00:04:52.691
You can see how this row is higher than
some of the other rows that are in this

94
00:04:52.691 --> 00:04:53.219
table.

95
00:04:53.219 --> 00:04:57.347
And then, of course,
you could take the entire table and

96
00:04:57.347 --> 00:05:00.885
resize that as well because
it's all one piece.

97
00:05:00.885 --> 00:05:04.572
Now how do I get Into these
different pieces of the table?

98
00:05:04.572 --> 00:05:10.474
Because maybe I want to change
the row height or the column width or

99
00:05:10.474 --> 00:05:15.214
select a row to be able to
format this with bold text.

100
00:05:15.214 --> 00:05:19.716
How to select things within
a table is really important, and

101
00:05:19.716 --> 00:05:22.989
it all comes down to
your mouse cursor icon.

102
00:05:22.989 --> 00:05:26.166
What does that mouse cursor look
like when you're over something?

103
00:05:26.166 --> 00:05:27.825
And in a table,
you actually have a lot of them.

104
00:05:27.825 --> 00:05:30.701
So let me show you a few of them,
and I'm just gonna be hovering.

105
00:05:30.701 --> 00:05:35.473
I'm gonna try to go ahead and
zoom in so you can see this little bit.

106
00:05:35.473 --> 00:05:40.108
You see if I'm hovering above with
this black arrow pointing down, if you

107
00:05:40.108 --> 00:05:45.063
clicked right now, that would indicate
that you would be selecting a column.

108
00:05:45.063 --> 00:05:47.195
And I'm gonna go ahead and do it just so

109
00:05:47.195 --> 00:05:50.405
you can see that it has selected
that particular column.

110
00:05:50.405 --> 00:05:52.743
And I'm just gonna click
off to deselect that.

111
00:05:52.743 --> 00:05:54.700
Let's go back in here.

112
00:05:54.700 --> 00:05:58.730
If I'm over too, there we go,
had to get close enough to it.

113
00:05:58.730 --> 00:05:59.850
I'm like, where is it?

114
00:05:59.850 --> 00:06:04.301
If I get close enough to it, the arrow
pointing to the right would indicate that

115
00:06:04.301 --> 00:06:06.201
I would select an entire column.

116
00:06:06.201 --> 00:06:13.139
But do you see how if I go right about
here, the arrow turns to a diagonal?

117
00:06:13.139 --> 00:06:15.273
And when you see that diagonal,

118
00:06:15.273 --> 00:06:19.711
that means you'd be selecting
the entire cell, not the eye beam.

119
00:06:19.711 --> 00:06:23.454
The eye beam means you'd
be selecting the text.

120
00:06:23.454 --> 00:06:28.861
So select the text versus select
the cell versus select the row,

121
00:06:28.861 --> 00:06:31.378
all within a very small area.

122
00:06:31.378 --> 00:06:33.906
And you might've seen
a couple more that popped in.

123
00:06:33.906 --> 00:06:38.592
Do you see where if I get right about
there, it's not exactly over it cuz I'm

124
00:06:38.592 --> 00:06:43.224
zoomed in, but there's two lines with
arrows pointing off the side of it?

125
00:06:43.224 --> 00:06:48.025
That means that I could change
the column width, okay.

126
00:06:48.025 --> 00:06:53.009
So I can move that column left or

127
00:06:53.009 --> 00:06:58.967
right to be able to change that size.

128
00:06:58.967 --> 00:06:59.987
If I come down here,
two lines with arrows on tops and bottoms,

129
00:06:59.987 --> 00:07:00.676
then you'd get changing the row height.

130
00:07:00.676 --> 00:07:03.065
Lots of different things all
right around a small area.

131
00:07:03.065 --> 00:07:07.113
Know what your mouse cursor
looks before you click it,

132
00:07:07.113 --> 00:07:10.107
cuz that's what it's gonna do, okay?

133
00:07:10.107 --> 00:07:13.370
So definitely wanted to point
that out cuz it's very important.

134
00:07:13.370 --> 00:07:15.020
I think people get very confused,

135
00:07:15.020 --> 00:07:19.670
very quickly of like,
it's not doing what I want it to do.

136
00:07:19.670 --> 00:07:20.235
Gotta watch the mouse.

137
00:07:20.235 --> 00:07:25.457
So be very, very careful about
watching your mouse cursor icons.

138
00:07:25.457 --> 00:07:28.281
And of course,
once you have things selected,

139
00:07:28.281 --> 00:07:30.334
you have your two pointed arrows.

140
00:07:30.334 --> 00:07:33.519
And that's where if I wanted to
resize that entire table, and

141
00:07:33.519 --> 00:07:35.119
I'll just do it really quick.

142
00:07:35.119 --> 00:07:40.091
It's gonna throw off all my arrows and
everything, but I can resize the entire,

143
00:07:40.091 --> 00:07:42.667
I could go ahead and get the column width.

144
00:07:42.667 --> 00:07:45.023
That would be, yes, I did the width,
okay, [LAUGH] height.

145
00:07:45.023 --> 00:07:50.075
I sometimes throw that width and
height around, but you can see that it's

146
00:07:50.075 --> 00:07:54.985
gonna go ahead and start changing all
the different pieces of my table.

147
00:07:54.985 --> 00:07:58.057
>> Now Vonne, when we start to take
a look at the overall notion of

148
00:07:58.057 --> 00:08:01.721
what you're trying to do with the table
there You're comparing, well,

149
00:08:01.721 --> 00:08:05.881
you're actually showing us two different
things that we're comparing, right?

150
00:08:05.881 --> 00:08:09.897
We're taking a look at your cats,
Fuego, and-

151
00:08:09.897 --> 00:08:10.508
>> Bishop.

152
00:08:10.508 --> 00:08:15.344
>> Bishop, and
one of them apparently sleeps or eats for

153
00:08:15.344 --> 00:08:17.394
six hours a [LAUGH] day.

154
00:08:17.394 --> 00:08:22.066
That's pretty hefty there overall, but
compared to Bishop apparently three times

155
00:08:22.066 --> 00:08:25.365
as much as Bishop and
you might wonder why it's important.

156
00:08:25.365 --> 00:08:28.150
Remember that PowerPoints
are about presentation right?

157
00:08:28.150 --> 00:08:31.880
The information that you want to display
here has to be displayed in an orderly

158
00:08:31.880 --> 00:08:35.710
manner and has to make sense to
whoever's going to be looking at it.

159
00:08:35.710 --> 00:08:38.880
It would do no good for
us just to display random information so

160
00:08:38.880 --> 00:08:42.890
what Yvonne has done here is showing
us a comparison of cat activity,

161
00:08:42.890 --> 00:08:45.345
which I didn't know that there
was such a thing as cat activity.

162
00:08:45.345 --> 00:08:46.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> To tell you the truth,

163
00:08:46.210 --> 00:08:50.285
mine sleeps and I don't know about play,
cuz I'm never home.

164
00:08:50.285 --> 00:08:52.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> But sleeps and

165
00:08:52.020 --> 00:08:53.430
eats are the two that I know about.

166
00:08:53.430 --> 00:08:58.915
But the very fact that your cat
actually eats for six hours a day.

167
00:08:58.915 --> 00:09:02.170
I would say indicates
maybe a visit to the vet.

168
00:09:02.170 --> 00:09:05.335
[LAUGH]
>> Well we actually have had the vet

That was starting to bug me [LAUGH].

That's why it was doing that.

618

So see, I did the same thing it's

619
00:33:35.410 --> 00:33:38.060
I have to go back and
remember select to effect,

620
00:33:38.060 --> 00:33:41.970

And that pretty much covers

And everything that you could

But really on one slide.

00:34:05.590 --> 00:34:08.890
So Vonne showed us not only

also of course how to create a table and

630
00:34:10.810 --> 00:34:14.538
then format it to make it look the way

631

Well that's a great place for

00:34:16.138 --> 00:34:19.262
For ITProTV I've been
your host Ronnie Wong.

00:34:22.831 --> 00:34:26.990
[MUSIC]

00:34:26.990 --> 00:34:34.221
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne discuss the purpose and creation of charts in Microsoft PowerPoint. Charts allow us to summarize and compare data in graphical representation. Vonne reviews the terminology associated with charts, chart types, how to insert a chart, add data to a chart, add and modify chart elements, as well as format charts for a presentation.
episodes.title: Charts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

So a line graph, or sorry,
a line chart, graphs and charts you can

165

In the 24 hours in the day,

It's just instead of this way,
it's this way.

00:10:23.470 --> 00:10:25.430
And there's some other

There's a box and whisker,

00:24:03.960 --> 00:24:06.770
If I single click,
notice how one, two, three, four.

420
00:24:06.770 --> 00:24:08.440
All four data series are selected.

421
00:24:08.440 --> 00:24:10.140
I can see the dots on each one.

422
00:24:10.140 --> 00:24:16.560
If I single clicked one more time, see
how I've isolated just that first column.

423
00:24:16.560 --> 00:24:21.440
And then I apply a gradient here it's
only going to one, so just watch that.

424
00:24:21.440 --> 00:24:26.510
If you are formatting data series
individually for the different fills and

425
00:24:26.510 --> 00:24:31.290
everything, you can deselect all
of them if you wanna say and

426
00:24:31.290 --> 00:24:34.230
just focus on one of them.

427
00:24:34.230 --> 00:24:37.810
Which can be beneficial, especially if
you're doing a pie chart you might wanna

428
00:24:37.810 --> 00:24:39.590
make sure you're like okay, single click.

429
00:24:39.590 --> 00:24:43.160
Then single click again to be
able to isolate that one piece.

430
00:24:44.360 --> 00:24:44.970
>> All right, Vonne.

431
00:24:44.970 --> 00:24:49.310
Now taking a look at that on the screen
there's this plus sign that looks

432
00:24:49.310 --> 00:24:52.080
like a paintbrush and a funnel.

433
00:24:52.080 --> 00:24:53.040
What is that about?

434
00:24:53.040 --> 00:24:55.840
>> Yeah, these are new buttons or
newer buttons.

435
00:24:55.840 --> 00:24:58.440
I don't remember them in
older versions of PowerPoint.

436
00:24:58.440 --> 00:25:04.340
That will allow you to do things like
format and the funnel, it's like a filter.

437
00:25:04.340 --> 00:25:05.770
Like filtering your data.

438
00:25:05.770 --> 00:25:10.900
So remember how we said,
why I didn't wanna have four categories or

439
00:25:10.900 --> 00:25:14.110
three categories and
I didn't wanna have three series.

440
00:25:14.110 --> 00:25:15.109
Right?
We didn't have three cast.

441
00:25:16.110 --> 00:25:20.390
I'm gonna close this task pane,
you could go ahead and click on that and

442
00:25:20.390 --> 00:25:23.900
what it does is it brings up,
well these are the different pieces.

443
00:25:23.900 --> 00:25:25.920
Well, what if you didn't
want to show this?

444
00:25:25.920 --> 00:25:27.795
I don't wanna show Meow.

445
00:25:27.795 --> 00:25:30.935
Well, I can uncheck it and then apply.

446
00:25:30.935 --> 00:25:35.605
And then it's only going to display sleep,
eat, and play.

447
00:25:35.605 --> 00:25:38.635
>> Nice.
>> And if only wanted to compare Fuego and

448
00:25:38.635 --> 00:25:40.225
not Bishop, I can uncheck that.

449
00:25:40.225 --> 00:25:41.790
You always gotta click the apply button.

450
00:25:41.790 --> 00:25:44.115
Cuz people will check and
like, it's not doing anything.

451
00:25:44.115 --> 00:25:46.075
But you gotta apply the changes.

452
00:25:46.075 --> 00:25:47.575
It's really, it's almost like hiding.

453
00:25:47.575 --> 00:25:49.475
It's just hiding that information.

454
00:25:49.475 --> 00:25:53.942
It's not deleting it like we had done in
the chart data, but it is just hiding.

455
00:25:53.942 --> 00:25:55.610
So it's nice.

456
00:25:55.610 --> 00:25:58.400
l really do like that if
you wanted a quick and

457
00:25:58.400 --> 00:26:03.230
easy way to just say filter out
the data that l want to show.

458
00:26:03.230 --> 00:26:07.090
And then the paint brush would
be how you can add those styles.

459
00:26:07.090 --> 00:26:10.860
All the things we see in the design tab on
the ribbon, you could go through and start

460
00:26:10.860 --> 00:26:14.850
changing some of these like maybe the
overall color scheme that l want to use.

461
00:26:14.850 --> 00:26:16.660
Now I've still have got
that yellow background, so

462
00:26:16.660 --> 00:26:19.230
it's not looking so fantastic right now.

463
00:26:20.420 --> 00:26:23.490
But those are nice little quick and
easy buttons, and

464
00:26:23.490 --> 00:26:26.530
then the little plus sign would
be your different chart elements.

465
00:26:26.530 --> 00:26:28.140
>> Nice.
>> That we had done through the ribbon,

466
00:26:28.140 --> 00:26:30.790
but it's just another way
because there's always

467
00:26:30.790 --> 00:26:32.970
like 15 ways to do
something in PowerPoint.

468
00:26:32.970 --> 00:26:38.430
It's just adding you another place
to go for those little buttons.

469
00:26:38.430 --> 00:26:43.790
Now coming back to the data, hiding
some I didn't wanna compare the Meow.

470
00:26:43.790 --> 00:26:49.540
And sorry I have to do this, I have to
go ahead and take this fill off of that.

471
00:26:51.860 --> 00:26:53.410
Come on stop, okay come here.

472
00:26:53.410 --> 00:26:54.360
All right there we go.

473
00:26:54.360 --> 00:26:58.190
The no fill would then just go back to
whatever the chart style is going to be.

474
00:26:58.190 --> 00:27:01.470
And sorry, that was a little jarring,
I don't know if anybody else is like

475
00:27:01.470 --> 00:27:04.290
please just turn it off,
give me some sunglasses.

476
00:27:04.290 --> 00:27:07.410
So I wanted to at least format
that plot area to take it off.

477
00:27:07.410 --> 00:27:13.270
So data, what if we made a mistake and
Fuego is not sleeping as much anymore?

478
00:27:13.270 --> 00:27:15.410
Or he's playing more?

479
00:27:15.410 --> 00:27:18.020
Something to that effect,
I need to edit that data.

480
00:27:18.020 --> 00:27:21.460
That's where you can go
to the edit data button.

481
00:27:21.460 --> 00:27:26.570
And then it just brings up that little
window in an Excel like format,

482
00:27:26.570 --> 00:27:27.842
and then I can change it.

483
00:27:27.842 --> 00:27:35.320
Because maybe Bishop plays two hours and
meows six hours, eight hours?

484
00:27:35.320 --> 00:27:36.200
Where are we at?

485
00:27:36.200 --> 00:27:38.190
Math.
>> [LAUGH]

486
00:27:38.190 --> 00:27:39.375
>> We'll go with eight.

487
00:27:39.375 --> 00:27:41.010
[LAUGH] So we could go ahead.

488
00:27:41.010 --> 00:27:41.830
And is that 24?

489
00:27:41.830 --> 00:27:42.470
>> Sure.

490
00:27:42.470 --> 00:27:44.023
>> Okay, good.
I was hoping that was right.

491
00:27:44.023 --> 00:27:46.610
[LAUGH] So I went ahead and
changed my data.

492
00:27:46.610 --> 00:27:50.510
And if I close this,
now you can see that it didn't change.

493
00:27:50.510 --> 00:27:52.280
Why did it not change?

494
00:27:55.020 --> 00:27:58.110
There we go.
Remember that weird glitch I was having?

495
00:27:58.110 --> 00:28:01.680
It didn't actually close PowerPoint
it just didn't display properly.

496
00:28:01.680 --> 00:28:03.790
So all right, that was a me thing.

497
00:28:03.790 --> 00:28:05.960
It should work fine with you.

498
00:28:05.960 --> 00:28:08.240
And the other thing I
wanted to show you here is,

499
00:28:08.240 --> 00:28:10.640
what if I wanted to change the chart type?

500
00:28:10.640 --> 00:28:13.020
We had talked about that I
wanted a clustered column.

501
00:28:13.020 --> 00:28:16.860
With out the 3D effect,
well maybe I want the 3D effect now.

502
00:28:16.860 --> 00:28:19.440
Change chart type,
we have our button right there.

503
00:28:19.440 --> 00:28:23.860
And then you could go in to
adding a 3D clustered column,

504
00:28:23.860 --> 00:28:26.820
and then it would look
something like this.

505
00:28:26.820 --> 00:28:30.700
Maybe I want to change it to a line chart,
or a line graph.

506
00:28:30.700 --> 00:28:35.730
Okay well this doesn't
really represent the data

507
00:28:35.730 --> 00:28:40.730
I feel in cat activity, but
I could change it if I wanted to.

508
00:28:40.730 --> 00:28:43.830
And I could do the bar charts and
so on and so forth.

509
00:28:43.830 --> 00:28:48.820
But you could go ahead and change your
chart types really quickly by going into

510
00:28:48.820 --> 00:28:50.460
your contextual tabs on your ribbon.

511
00:28:50.460 --> 00:28:51.650
Let's go ahead and switch that back.

512
00:28:52.720 --> 00:28:58.670
The other thing was what if I
wanted to switch my axis basically.

513
00:28:58.670 --> 00:29:02.890
So I want to have the activities
as the legend, and Fuego and

514
00:29:02.890 --> 00:29:05.630
Bishop along the category axis.

515
00:29:05.630 --> 00:29:09.160
Where it says select data, now notice
it doesn't switch row and column,

516
00:29:09.160 --> 00:29:10.950
it's not selected right now.

517
00:29:10.950 --> 00:29:12.460
That's okay, cuz if it's not,

518
00:29:12.460 --> 00:29:17.058
if it's grayed out there is a way that you
can do it if where if you go to select

519
00:29:17.058 --> 00:29:22.050
data it brings up this extra window
where it says select data source.

520
00:29:22.050 --> 00:29:26.180
And you see right there where
it says switch row and column.

521
00:29:26.180 --> 00:29:28.940
So if it doesn't give it to you by
default, just go into there and

522
00:29:28.940 --> 00:29:31.757
then force it to say I
wanna turn this around.

523
00:29:31.757 --> 00:29:35.803
And if anybody's coming from
older versions of Excel,

524
00:29:35.803 --> 00:29:38.940
to me this is like an old school box.

525
00:29:38.940 --> 00:29:41.620
It reminds me of the older
ways that you had to do, and

526
00:29:41.620 --> 00:29:44.060
you had to this kind
of know what this was.

527
00:29:44.060 --> 00:29:45.982
And it didn't really
give you that preview,

528
00:29:45.982 --> 00:29:47.950
before you put all the information in.

529
00:29:47.950 --> 00:29:50.480
So I'm just gonna go ahead, and
click okay and you can see.

530
00:29:50.480 --> 00:29:56.230
That now it's switch to where we're
having Fuego as the category and

531
00:29:56.230 --> 00:30:02.230
the activities as the legends and
the data series that we're going across.

532
00:30:02.230 --> 00:30:03.680
And so that's how you can change that.

533
00:30:03.680 --> 00:30:06.710
I'm gonna close this, yep,
see it did that little glitch thing again.

534
00:30:06.710 --> 00:30:09.280
That's okay, and
then we come back to our chart and

535
00:30:09.280 --> 00:30:12.260
we can keep on formatting
if you wanted to.

536
00:30:12.260 --> 00:30:15.370
If you go over to the format,
that's where if you did want to go and

537
00:30:15.370 --> 00:30:21.668
format each individual item you could,
as we displayed in the beginning.

538
00:30:21.668 --> 00:30:28.100
But I think that covers just about
everything in inserting charts.

539
00:30:28.100 --> 00:30:28.940
>> All right, Vonne.

540
00:30:28.940 --> 00:30:30.870
Well, thank you again for helping us out,

541
00:30:30.870 --> 00:30:34.600
in terms of taking a look at using
charts inside of PowerPoint.

542
00:30:34.600 --> 00:30:38.300
Remember that when we want to be able
to display a tremendous amount of

543
00:30:38.300 --> 00:30:41.910
information, charts are really good
in helping us to display summaries or

544
00:30:41.910 --> 00:30:44.940
trends or
be able to actually show percentages too.

545
00:30:44.940 --> 00:30:48.080
So depending on what we actually need to
show, PowerPoint gives us the way to do

546
00:30:48.080 --> 00:30:52.120
that without having to bring in another
element to add in the PowerPoint.

547
00:30:52.120 --> 00:30:56.110
So as long as we can get the data into
a format that PowerPoint can recognize

548
00:30:56.110 --> 00:30:58.720
it can then apply all
the different formatting.

549
00:30:58.720 --> 00:31:01.430
We can change it to make
the presentation and

550
00:31:01.430 --> 00:31:03.620
the impact that we want
it to make as well.

551
00:31:03.620 --> 00:31:07.030
Thank you again, Vonne, for helping us
to take a look at inserting charts.

552
00:31:07.030 --> 00:31:08.710
And thank you also for watching.

553
00:31:08.710 --> 00:31:10.870
It's a great place for
us to go ahead and sign off.

554
00:31:10.870 --> 00:31:13.540
For IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

555
00:31:13.540 --> 00:31:14.520
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

556
00:31:14.520 --> 00:31:18.562
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Microsoft PowerPoint 2016.

557
00:31:18.562 --> 00:31:28.562
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Mike discuss how to add animations to a PowerPoint presentation. They demonstrate adding basic animations, modifying animations and adding multiple animations. They also look at using motion paths and custom paths with animations. They finish up by demonstrating adding sounds to animations and using animations with SmartArt.
episodes.title: Animation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.240
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:02.154
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.154 --> 00:00:06.079
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.079 --> 00:00:08.253
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.253 --> 00:00:11.926
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.926 --> 00:00:14.670
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

7
00:00:14.670 --> 00:00:17.260
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

8
00:00:17.260 --> 00:00:19.966
And today we're doing our PowerPoint 2016.

9
00:00:19.966 --> 00:00:22.879
And specifically in this episode,
we're gonna be looking at animation.

10
00:00:22.879 --> 00:00:27.502
And here to show us how to move things
around within our PowerPoint presentation

11
00:00:27.502 --> 00:00:28.660
is Ms Vonne Smith.

12
00:00:28.660 --> 00:00:29.199
How you doing, Vonne?

13
00:00:29.199 --> 00:00:30.690
>> Good, I'm glad to be here.

14
00:00:30.690 --> 00:00:35.186
I'm excited to get moving in PowerPoint,
you see what I did there?

15
00:00:35.186 --> 00:00:35.960
>> I did.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,

16
00:00:35.960 --> 00:00:39.380
I'm going to be animating our
slide content in PowerPoint.

17
00:00:39.380 --> 00:00:42.813
So, animation is exactly what
you think it sounds like,

18
00:00:42.813 --> 00:00:47.605
we're going to animate objects or text or
anything that's on our slides to make

19

it a little bit more fun,
get a little bit more possessed, and

20
00:00:51.320 --> 00:00:56.080

could get a little more lively.

21
00:00:56.080 --> 00:00:59.380
>> Yeah, I like that, cuz when you think
of PowerPoint, you think a very static,

22
00:00:59.380 --> 00:01:02.600
here is some bullet points,
we're gonna talk about this but,

23
00:01:02.600 --> 00:01:05.920
if I can make things move around,
put a little animation in there.

24
00:01:05.920 --> 00:01:09.590
Like you said, I can kinda bring some life
into my PowerPoint presentation which is

25
00:01:09.590 --> 00:01:12.320
gonna keep the people from going to sleep
while you're giving your presentation.

26
00:01:12.320 --> 00:01:15.070
>> Yes, and
it can help you control the pace

27
00:01:15.070 --> 00:01:17.850
of the content that you want
to present in your slides.

28
00:01:17.850 --> 00:01:19.791
Now of course with anything,
you go overboard it,

29
00:01:19.791 --> 00:01:21.339
can get a little obnoxious, I'm sure.

30
00:01:21.339 --> 00:01:22.312
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

00:01:22.312 --> 00:01:25.510
always thinking about
your target audience.

32
00:01:25.510 --> 00:01:27.380

33

If you're going for
middle school children, well,

34
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:32.320
they might think it might
be little too much,

35

but, how about elementary school
children or kindergartens?

36
00:01:35.430 --> 00:01:36.698
They would love animation.

37
00:01:36.698 --> 00:01:41.339
But if you're giving a presentation to the
boardroom, you might wanna do some subtle

38
00:01:41.339 --> 00:01:45.272
animation and be able to have that kind
of move the presentation along and

39
00:01:45.272 --> 00:01:48.654
not make them go, whoa,
that's too much, you need to stop.

40
00:01:48.654 --> 00:01:51.160
[LAUGH]
>> So what are really animating then?

41

Cuz it's not like we're making
a flash movie or a cartoon or

42
00:01:53.950 --> 00:01:57.470

what are we animating within PowerPoint?

43
00:01:57.470 --> 00:01:59.738
>> Well, why don't we go ahead and
jump into it and

44
00:01:59.738 --> 00:02:02.424
I can show you some different
things that we can do in it.

45
00:02:02.424 --> 00:02:06.900
So, I have a PowerPoint presentation
already created called animations.

46
00:02:06.900 --> 00:02:08.764
And, it's going to go head and

47
00:02:08.764 --> 00:02:12.217
open up with a design template
that's already applied.

48
00:02:12.217 --> 00:02:15.991
And I have some of the slides that you've
been seeing, some of the content that

49
00:02:15.991 --> 00:02:19.652
we've been doing throughout the entire
show with our Alice in Wonderland,

50
00:02:19.652 --> 00:02:23.596
if you haven't caught along to that, with

51
00:02:23.596 --> 00:02:26.490
things like that in a different

52
00:02:26.490 --> 00:02:31.339
And along the way, I've made some notes in

53
00:02:31.339 --> 00:02:35.535
to help me guide you along and
how we can go ahead and add our animation.

54
00:02:35.535 --> 00:02:39.752
So, why don't we start at the very
beginning on slide two of our just basic

55
00:02:39.752 --> 00:02:40.508

56
00:02:40.508 --> 00:02:44.580
And you've actually seen some of these

57
00:02:44.580 --> 00:02:47.921
PowerPoint when we were doing
with Fuego and Bishop, the cats.

58
00:02:47.921 --> 00:02:52.140
I decided to take a break from them,

59
00:02:52.140 --> 00:02:53.955
I still have a cat in there, so.

60
00:02:53.955 --> 00:02:55.212
>> [LAUGH] Of course.
>> [LAUGH] Can't get away from that one.

61
00:02:55.212 --> 00:02:59.685
All right, so if I was going to play
this slide from this particular slide,

62
00:02:59.685 --> 00:03:03.320

63
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:05.400
All the informations up
